Just Do It!. Along with this Piazza, the Pantheon is arguably the best place to stay in Rome. I stayed in that area and I LOVED IT! Piazza Navona is just sort of fun to walk through. It's meant as a community gathering place though, and in this case, the community is consisted of tourists.

Lively scene, no flower pushers, lots of art. This was a wonderful experience. We browsed the many paintings for sale and even had our caricature done. First for both of us. There was a few artists creating spray paint pieces, very impressive to watch. We just really loved this area.

full of life. full of people, terraces, gellato, painters, dancers, singers, and around this square are the narrowest streets with most of those tiny terraces and small tables and there is still traffic, the can actually take your food off the table while driving!

Magical Place!. We love this Piazza. It's our second time in Rome, and this Piazza is a special place. The beautiful fountains and artwork on display are amazing. It's nice to sit at one of the cafes for a snack and glass of wine to watch the people. Lots of energy here in this historic location.

Beautiful place to soak in the spirit of Rome. Sit by Bernini's fountain of the four rivers and just soak in the Roman spirit. It's a beautiful square that fills you with a sense of peace and calm. The artists selling their works and the restaurants surrounding the area make it a lovely and lively atmosphere. The restaurants right at the square are a little expensive and you would see a drop in price just round the corner.

don't miss this spot!. we walked there from the trevi fountain and the pantheon. the piazza was full of life, many artist offering their work(I bought a couple nice water color prints) bars, restaurants, etc..

Splendid. What a magnificent square!!!!...Love the artists around, the little shops, restaurants, cafes, fountains...the wonderful architecture... I didn't want to leave!!! Had good weather, sunny with a few clouds... Can't wait to go back!
Beautiful. This is a beautiful area, fun to sit and eat while the people stroll by. We went Easter week so it was crowded. Worn the visit though, especially in the evening when the fountains are lit.

People watching supreme, a great place to watch the world go by. Before (and after) having lunch at Restaurant Panzirone in the Piazza, we walked around Piazza Novona a few times, each time noticing different things going on, all the different beautiful buildings, the market stalls selling mostly drawings and paintings.This is just a beautiful piazza to spend some time in and take in the surroundings and when you're done there, the pantheon is just around the corner, or enjoy lunch or dinner at one of the restaurants in the square (be care though, they are expensive in comparison to other places in Rome).Apart from watching everything and everyone go about their business in the piazza, one of my favorite parts of this Piazza was watching the unlicensed sellers peddling their counterfeit bags etc bolt every time a police officer would come around the corner. It would seem they have police continually patrolling the piazza as we saw them high-tail quite often.

Beautifully Historic. As with many Piazza in Roma, the edges are surrounded by cafes, bars and restaurants. The centre, however is amazingly sculptured. The focal fountain depicts the four major world rivers and is a nod towards the Roman respect for the power of water. I won't give up its secret, however a read of the information in the piazza will tell the history of not only this piazza, but also of why there are fountains in almost every piazza in Rome.

Expensive gelato. Good but expensive, nice area though, kind of a small walking mall with restaurants, bars and gelato!!! Better gelato and prices at Aperitif S.R.L. on Via Di Ripetta, 71, Rome...now that's value for money!

My fav piazza in Roma !. Walkin into piazza navona from one of the streets is like suddenly walking into a buzzing artisty foodie musical place .....it's been my fav so far, just watching the artists are work....eateries buzzing with people and musicians around ..makes this place special .
Fantastic place. Piazza Navona is a beautiful place with a lot of artists. There are also many restaurants. A nice place to walk, to admire the amazing fountains and sculptures!

Watch the World go by while in a stunning location. This was a favourite to stop with a glass of wine and just take it in, the fountains are amazing as are the stunning artists and stalls in the square.
Our only regret was not having the chance to visit here at night, I'm sure it would have been even more amazing!
A good reason to visit Rome again!

Favorito spot in Roma. This is a very beautifull piazza, one of the most important in Rome. I liked a lot, specially because you have lots of people just resting, playing music, there's restaurants and caffès. You can drink something or just enjoy the environment with fresh air from the foutains in The meadle of the piazza! Don't miss this Place!
Beautiful. Beautiful piazza, nice place to stroll and wander. Many choices as well as food and coffee are concerned; a bit overpriced,though.

Happy we made the stop. This square contains 3 very large public fountains that brought fresh water to the early Romans. It's like a large Arts Festival where you can watch artists painting (and of course purchase works) and also several 'live' statues--very entertaining! Definitely a hidden must-see.
The most beautiful square in Rome. The most beautiful square in Rome. Beautiful fountains, lots of restaurants, and lots of artists displaying paintings. Just a lovely place to spend some time!

night and day, such a difference. A beautiful place, safe as policemen walk around during the day. Some interesting paintings, although didn't see anyone painting, just selling prints! a lot of street sellers bothering us though, best to ignore them. Restaurants a bit pricey so best avoid them and go on the side streets as atmosphere more authentic!The fountain is the most beautiful, especially at night when it is lit up. We got to go inside the church which was opened, and that is a magnificent building!

Interesting to see good artists. It's an interesting place to walk around. You will see a lot of local artists selling their art. It seems to be done well but presented poorly because they are trying to sell just the canvas and it's not framed. It might like beautiful at night as the 3 fountains could be nice under the lights.

Not the heart of Rome, surely?. We enjoyed walking around the square, viewed the fountain. It was good to be in a more open space and to read about the history of Piazza Navona from our guide book. A great place to breathe again, after the excitement and bustle in the streets on the way.However if you are planning a visit, be aware this is a tourist set up. The crummy 'art' was surely mass produced tat? I didn't feel we were really part of a typically Roman square, any more than I would believe Leicester Square in London is 'typically English'.I bought my daughter some cheap sunglasses from a seller, I decided what I would pay and just kept nicely saying the same amount until he dropped his price to mine :) he seemed happy and so was I.The café waiters on the square tried to get us to sit in for coffee but when he told me it was 7 euros I declined, and we walked to the pretty cafe inside the huge gates to the museum at the end of the square. Lovely staff and delicious (less costly) coffee.As part of wandering around Rome this was a nice place but not a must-see and don't kid yourselves about the stalls and sellers.

A hidden jewel. Rome is one magnificent masterpiece but tucked away from the grandeur is a hidden jewel - Piazza Navona. Enter slowly and walk around the small rectangle. Stop at the Bernini fountain. View it from all angles. See also the other complementary creations. If you can, before your visit, browse through some information about this piazza (wikipedia will do) and you'll understand why nobody is ever tired of Rome.

Stroll, buy some gelato, and some art. My wife and I found ourselves strolling through this amazing piazza several times over a week. We bought art, we bought gelato, we stared at fountains, and watched the lively crowd. Day or night this is a great place to hang out.
Most popular Piazza in Rome. Nice cafe´s and restaurants sourrounding this fantastic scene - and so much culture on the same Piazza, with it´s lovely fontaines.

Piazza Navona. This is perhaps the most famous plaza in Rome, and is always busy. There are plenty of street venders selling every thing from hand painted replicas of famous paintings to laser pointers. The cafes that encompass the plaza are just there for tourists, so walk a few blocks before dining. One one end of the plaza is a fountain designed by Bernini. The four figures represent the four main rivers of the world. Have a nice trip :)

For a lot of fun!. The piazza was a lot of fun! There are a lot of people just gathering and talking, a lot of art dealers and shops. The food is excellent around the piazza. Usually there are some street performers that will keep you entertained. I always enjoyed just people watching and watching the happenings of the neighborhood.

Sell sell sell. This is a stunning piazza with beautiful architecture and fascades. Unfortunately, because it is so beautiful it attracts lots of tourists...which means lots of touts selling tat and trinkets that badger you with every step, p*****g you off so much that you get grumpy and hacked off not having enjoyed the place to the full...might be just me. Certainly a sight to see...but best from the safety of a table several rows back at one of the many lovely restaurants.

Its okay. Not too bad, but not sure what all the fuss is about either. Lots of people and touristy paintings. I had good ice cream there but the square at the Pantheon was much more lively and felt like a better place to while away the time. If its on your way, take a few minutes for a stroll. Maybe its more beautiful at night
fun spot. plenty of restaurants and shops on and around. three fountains. beautiful sight. what else can you ask for?
Gorgeous. Loved it, we had a lovely meal at Roman Holiday (sorry, forgotten Italian). Gorgeous, spacious, stunning at night.

Art, food, people.. Piazza Navona is in the line from the Vatican to the Pantheon, Trevi Fountain, and Spanish Steps. It was an old chariot race track and is still shaped in an oval. I got some very good ice cream there, and it's a pleasant place to sit and watch people. Lots of paintings for sale too.

Beautiful square. I had no idea what to expect when my partner recommended us visiting here and we walked in at one end and I was really surprised at what a beautiful place this was. Restaurants all around, beautiful fountains, artists in the middle. We bought some beautiful paintings and also had a caricature done. It had a great atmosphere and we ate here twice both at different restaurants and both really nice food.

Nice place. Lovely piazza, full of tourists however so it is better to avoid the restaurants around. I don t want to generalise but we got here the worst pizza deal ever. Otherwise great atmosphere and many spots for amazing photos.

Lovely Piazza in Italy!. This was one of our favorite piazza's in Italy. The fountain in the center is beautiful, and all the restaurants and bars in the area were first-class. We ate dinner at one of the restaurants and it ended up being one of our favorite meals while in Rome!

Relax, Listen, Caffinate. We walked through this piazza several times. We spent time admiring the fountains. We sat in one of the many cafes and had cappuccino and a small snack. We listened to the jazz trio performing in the square. Browsed the artists. Avoided the vendors of trinkets. But mostly, it was just a nice place to be - it isn't about doing.

Beautiful. We stumbled across the Piazza on our first day in Rome whilst we were still getting our bearings.It is a wonderful place with 3 beautiful fountains and loads of lovely cafes and restaurants around the edges.Absolutely beautiful on a sunny day

Big enough to avoid the crowds. Love this Piazza - it's big, interesting and doesn't feel packed with people (unlike the Spanish Steps and the Trevi Fountain). Statues and Fountains are beautiful. Nice to sit and have coffee.

Nice place.... Went here in the evening... It was nice but very touristy... The place we ate had clearly 'Americanized' the food. Again, it was nice and a cool place to check out but skip the dining options here. They look nice but the food is Chef Boyardee.

great atmosphere - except the street sellers. a beautiful piazza filled with artists, artworks, stunning buildings and good restaurants.the only downside is the street sellers with their laser beams. they are putting laser on you and on these beautiful fountains and buildings, silly.
Awesome.... A gorgeous place to visit.. Lots of lovely restaurants, bars, gorgeous paintings to view.. 3 fountains and lots of artists. Its a heavenly place to relax and browse paintings
Piazza Navona - Rome, Italy. My first time in Rome was great! I saw so many magical, beautiful sites. The Piazza Navona was amazing! A must see in Roma!

Arguably the most beautiful piazza in the world. Definitely a must even if the restaurants are tourist traps and the crowds are a turn off. best times to visit are in the morning or at dusk. The three fountains are a marvel as is the shape of the piazza.

excellent fountains and good eats. The fountains make it famous. Some of them were moved from great distances to be in the center of rome. One of them has an armadillo (or so they think) which would be totally out of place in Rome. Art sellers fill the north end of the piazza. they are there for the tourists but who cares. It's lovely art. Had my first haggling experience with a vendor. there are plenty of places to eat nearby, but make sure to get off of the main piazza. Food quality improves exponentially as you get away from the main areas. So cliche but so true.
Not much worth talking about. It was alright. Weren't many shops open, and the ones that were we're nay tiny cafés not worth taking about. The fountains were beautiful, however.

Grab a table and a glass of wine and people-watch!. A bustling Piazza in the heart of Rome. After spending the morning in the outdoor market in the Campo di Fiori, take the short walk to Piazza Navona. After you walk around and take in the fountains and the street artists and painter, get a table at one of the many restaurants on the Piazza and enjoy some wine, snacks. One of the great places to sit and take in the multicultured city of Rome.

Better than the Spanish Steps. Spectacular sculptures, but often crowded. Like most of Rome, and most cities, best experienced on an early morning walk or run, when you can commune with these sights in a personal way

A beautiful and quiet piazza. Beautiful piazza very close to Pantheon (about three minutes walking distance). We went there on a rainy day and there were very few people there. Its a lovely place with nice cafes around. However on a sunny day, it was full of tourists and painters selling their paintings. Bernini's Fountain of the Four Rivers is worth seeing!!!

'Off the beaten track'. Okay, so Piazza Navona is not off the beaten track. It is, however, one of the lesser known yet very attractive squares that Rome has to offer. Nobody will hassle you for tours or anything else, and the atmosphere is generally relaxed. There's not a lot to do or see, but the fountains are pretty and if the weather's reasonable it's a nice place to take a few minutes and give yourself a break.

A Nicer Fountain than Trevi?. I really loved this fountain and square. We went in the middle of the day and it was not crowded at all. The fountain can be viewed from all angles, i.e. you can walk around it, which makes it much more friendly then the Trevi, which is best viewed only between the hours of Midnight and 8am due to the huge crowds attending. I recommend you take time to visit Piazza Navona, view and photograph the fountain at your leisure, and also have a look at the artists and their display of paintings and drawings on the northern side of the fountain.
Not really worth the walk. Heaving with tourists and mediocre artists selling work at silly prices. Very picturesque otherwise.

Vibrant place full of unexpected treasures!. Although it is not as commonly cited as the other attractions in Rome, this is definitely a place to visit! Situated a few minutes walk from the Pantheon, the piazza is a large area full of little shops, eateries and things to see! The baroque architecture is beautiful, as are the three fountains which are so detailed and bring character to the arena. As well as quaint shops there are several churches around the square and altogether it was a delightful atmosphere, if a little busy!

Nice square but not as good a reviews make it. We visited based on reviews. Whilst we had a lovely time, I'm not sure why people raved about it so much to be honest. Pretty fountains otherwise just full of tourist bars
Fabulous place, vibrant and exciting. Huge Piazza, full of people, local tradesmen, artists, cafes and restaurants. Do not miss this place.

Full of Tourists but Still Lovely. The long and narrow Piazza Navona preserves the outlines of a stadium from Classical Rome. It is usually full of tourists and people trying to sell things to tourists, so on a nice day or evening, it is very crowded. In spite of that, it is an interesting place to visit any time. Of the three fountains, the central one by Bernini, alone, is worth the effort. We wandered through it several times, including our last night in Rome, when we bought some gelato and enjoyed people-watching. The Baroque buildings on the west side are really lovely, and on that evening, the church of Sant' Agnese was open for mass and one room in the Palazzo Pamphilj was lit so we could partially see the ceiling fresco, both adding to the atmosphere.

Don't miss this Piazza!. Amazing fountains (3) and many restaurants. So glad we made it a point to see this particular Piazza otherwise we would have missed a great site. It was a great place for the kids to unwind and run around while we sipped our coffee and rested. And it was free!!!

Nice place with lots of eateries. A place with lots of buskers and artists with their paintbrushes who would paint absolutely anything beautiful, such as your portrait. I got one done by a lady with black curly locks. She was good. Worth getting into one of the eateries and sitting outside to view the world go by your face.
Very nice square - free to visit. Many restaurants. Nice open square with huge fountains. Many restaurants in the square if you are looking for somewhere not on a main road - don't know the prices.

Go at night. One of the biggest and I'm guessing surely the longest square (actually an oval) which houses the Brazilian embassy in a beautiful building and Bernini's fountain of 4 rivers this Piazza is quieter by the day with only tourists and painters flocking but happening by night with the restaurants brimming. If you have limited time, then I would recommend Campo de Fiori by morning and Piazza Navona by evening/night. However, its best to visit early in the morning if you want to capture great shots of the fountains.
ART WORK-HORSE RIDES AND AMAZING DISHES FOR THE CHEAPEST PRICE. GREAT AREA TO COME FOR DINNER ----HAVE TO FIND THEM IN THE thin little streets around--artists-cafes--horserides and handmade items

Fountains and statues all over the place.. The Piazza Navona is situated in the historic centre of Rome, west of the Pantheon and is one of Rome's liveliest squares, with many outdoor cafes, restaurants and night clubs in the neighbourhood. It gets busy both day and night, with tourists, souvenir sellers and artists. Get here early in the day or later in the evening for a walk after dinner.The square is built on the former Stadium of Domitian, built by Emperor Domitian in 86 AD. This accounts for the long, oval shape of the square. The main attraction of Piazza Navona is the trio of fountains that adorn the square. The central and largest fountain is the Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi (Fountain of the Four Rivers). It was constructed between 1647 and 1651 on request of pope Innocent X. The design of the fountain was first commissioned to Borromini, but it was ultimately handed to his rival Bernini. The fountain features four figures, each representing a river from a different continent - the Nile, Ganges, Danube and Rio de la Plata. The statues are at the base of a rock supporting an obelisk, originally located at the Massenzio Circus, near the Appian Way.The two other fountains on the piazza are the Fontana del Nettuno (Neptune fountain) at the northern end and the Fontana del Moro (Moor fountain) at the southern end of the square. The Fontana del Nettuno, also known as the Calderari, was built in 1576 by Giacomo della Porta. The statues of Neptune surrounded by sea nymphs were added in the 19th century. Giacomo della Porta also built the Fontana del Moro. The central statue of a Moor holding a dolphin, a design by Bernini, was added in the 17th century. The tritons are 19th century additions.Another highlight at Navona square is the church of Sant'Agnese in Agone. It was commissioned in 1652 by Pope Innocent X and built on the site where according to legend, St. Agnes was stripped naked, but miraculously saved from disgrace by extraordinary growth of hair. The front facade of the Baroque church was designed by Borromini, Bernini's main rival. Construction started just two years after the completion of Bernini's Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi, right in front of the building. The church was completed in 1670.We were lucky enough to get here when an evening Mass was being said - moving, though I am not a Catholic.

Lively and beautiful square. Surrounded on three sides by somewhat pricey but mostly indistinguishable restaurants, this lively square offers street theater and musicians plus a host of items for sale, whether art or leather purses. Clearly aimed at tourists it nevertheless seems to capture the spirit of a truly cosmopolitan city and is well worth hanging out in, especially in late afternoon or evening.

Navona Feb 16 2013. In the Centre of Italy, a Piazza with three highly intricate fountains resides. The central masterpiece is stunning and the ambiance of the trickling water, blended with the stunning array of colour from the artists' work makes Piazza Navona ideal for several minutes to absorb a truly tranquil atmosphere. It is quite true what the other reviewers have said, the variation of art works on display are mesmorising at best, while others - not so much. Nevertheless it can't be argued that the location is perfect. With several gelateriae serving up reasonably priced, good quality ice cream on hot days, in addition to the small, quintessentially Roman style restaurants dotted around the outskirt of the piazza, providing an exquisite view of the bustle of artists and the beauty of the fountains.

People-watching heaven. Piazza Navona is probably the best open space in Rome for people-watching, with the possible exception of the Spanish Steps. One side of the piazza is lined with good quality cafes and restaurants , while the other is splendid church and palace facades. The open space contains great fountains and impressive street theatre. I'd recommend a simple Roman pizza and beer at lunch time to enjoy the spectacle.

the square of the artists!. Literally, you step in this piazza, and there are bunch of artists from around the world, drawing, painting, selling different kinds of artistic works that you don't know if you should look at the roman architecture around the square or to look at the artists making magic with their pencils. Of course, the buildings around the piazza and the fountain in the center of it are impressive things. However, I was more surprised by all the modern art that is going on there.
Beautiful. Worth a visit. Great place to relax soak up the beautiful buildings and have a cafe or pizza. Make sure you go inside the cathedral in the piazza.

Just lovely!. I wanted to visit this square because it was in the film Angels & Demons (I know - but I'm a massive Dan Brown fan!). We went here for dinner one night and were even able to eat outside - all the restaurants have outdoor heaters. We went back again during the day and sat in the sun listening to music and enjoying a beer! Beautiful fountains, lovely place to spend the afternoon.
The Best Square. Really it is the best square. Beautiful architecture. Everything is there. You have to see it. Just like the other Rome Attractions. Do not miss it.
The best square of the world. After a long walks arround Rome sitting in Piazza Navona is just perfect for having a nice proscuttio and a glass of red wine. Sit for hours and you will not be boring.

I love this place. Its like Rome within Rome complete with beautiful architecture, stunning statues, mini Piazzas restaurants, shops and locals and tourists alike. Well worth a stroll or maybe a coffee or meal whilst spending time watching the world go by. There are a myriad of side streets to explore which hold equally pleasing but less expensive eating establishments, including the ubiquitous Irish Bar (with Guinness!)
Fabulose. One of the best plazas and churchs in the world, And the place of several movies locationFine cristmas market

Lovely atmosphere. Full of ice cream shops, restaurants and cafés... Also the fountain of the four rivers. A lovely place to take a break whilst exploring Rome. Not too far from Trevi fountain and even the Vatican.
Artists. Close to apartment we stayed at. There are some excellent restaurants and shops in the area, as well as artists!
Enchanting. The amazing 17th Century fountain in the centre of this enchanting sunny square was loved by all our group. Definitely worth seeing

Beautiful.. Stunning decorative square in the city, even when we had a small down pour when entering the square. Fountains are very attractive and there is a nice feel to the place due mainly to the street artists, running water and very nice gelato available at the many retailers dotted around. Well worth a visit when in Rome.

The best Piazza in Rome. The one Piazza to rule them all. Everything is here - fountains, sculptures, obelisks, cafes, street performers and vendors. Click the photographs and then grab a coffee at one of the cafes. A very nice and lively ambiance. Tip: if interested in buying paintings as souveniers, this is the place to buy them as some artists themselves sell the paintings. They might cost a bit more than the souvenier shops, but they are all unique.
Worth going there. Brilliant atmosphere, best piazza we visited. Fountains are a sight to see. Sit and enjoy the view and atmosphere.
Worth a visit.. Lots of street vendors selling art. Be aware of drink prices...more expensive drinks in Rome. 16 euro for a peroni and house wine!

Classic Piazza. This is one of my favorite piazzas in Rome; churches, statues, fountains, ristorante, gelateria, cafes, street artists and musicians, even the requisite Egyptian obelisk can all be found here. Of course some would decry the crowds, congestion, panhandlers, and the touristy or tacky atmosphere that you often encounter, but I still think this Piazza is an experience not to be missed.A little background first. It is an elongated oval oriented along a norrh-south axis. It takes its shape from the former Ancient Roman stadium, Circus Agonalis, built in the 1st Century AD, that hosted not only fights and chariot races but would apparently be flooded for the purpose of aquatic games and staged naval battles. Nothing remains of the stadium except for a remnant of the wall found under buildings at the north end of the piazza; this intake and drainage point for water drawn from the Tiber River just a couple of blocks further north.Otherwise only the shape of the piazza is all that remains of the stadium. Replacing the stone stands that once seated an estimated 30,000 spectators are churches and palaces, some of them coloured yellow, ochre, and orange. In stead of faux naval ships there are 3 large fountain complexes or "Fontana": going north to south these are Fontana del Nettuno (of Neptune), Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi (of the 4 rivers), and Fontana del Moro IMoor). The 4 Rivers fountain is topped off with an obelisk. It was designed by the renowned Bernini (he also designed the colonnade around St. Peter's Square in the Vatican) and consists of 4 river gods representing the largest rivers known at the time: Danube (Europe), Nile (Atrica), Ganges (Asia) River Plate (the Americas). It was built in 1651. Each river god has particular identifying features. The Nile god has its head covered as the source ("head") of the river was as yet unknown. The river Plate or Plata has a pile of coins representing silver (plata in Spanish) representing the wealth of the New World.Right to the west of this fountain is the church of Sant'Agnese ISt. Agnes) built around the same time by a competitor, BorrominiTo the south of Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi, by the Fontana del Moro is the Palazzo Pamphilj which houses the Brazilian embassy.There are numerous places to eat at the Piazza Navona, and they obviously cater to tourists. Nevertheless, dining outside looking onto the piazza is a great way to spend time people-watching. In addition to numerous artists trying to sell their paintings there are musical performances taking place all around the piazza. Caricaturists and sketch artists will drawn their impressions of you, for a price, of course. Fellow-visitors crowd the place throughout the day, so if you want to experience a more serene Piazza Navona come early in the morning; it can still be noisy late at night.The Pantheon is a short walk away. Castel Sant'Angelo is a little further away but easily reached, and St. Peter's is not much farther away from there.Definitely find time to visit Piazza Navona when in Rome. Visit during the late afternoon and evening as the sun sets for a more mellow atmosphere. Never mind the crowds, just take it all in and enjoy.

Beautiful little piazza. This is an enormous and gorgeous piazza, fabulous for people-watching. The Bernini fountains are really wonderful, and you can spend a lot of time examining them, looking at the street artists and people-watching. The cafes around seem to be pretty tourist-heavy so explore nearby if you'd like somewhere to eat or drink.

It's awesome!. A masterpiece of baroque, this place with the shape of a roman stadium, is dominated by the three fountains, with evidence to the Fontana dei Fiume. The permanent crowds, the stalls, the street performers, make this place one of the liveliest in Rome.http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=XnNUV79hDSE

Great Piazza Navona!. This is my favorite piazza!it is located in the most graphical and colourful region of the historical centre!During the day.it is full of remarkable street artists.the three fountains are magnificent but the cafes and restaurants are too turistic.Α promenade nearby will give you the chance to explore amazing and cheapier places to eat or drink.

Neat Square. We passed through the Piazza on our way to the Pantheon. It's quite large and the fountains are lovely. The fountains may not be ad iconic as the Trevi and are a bit smaller, but absolutely worth seeing and hardly the crowds. There were several artists and people selling art set up in the square and it's lined with several cafes. So it pretty much looked like what you imagine Rome to be. We did have a cappuccino at one of the cafes. Yes, it was overpriced, but a cool experience we'll remember. We didn't mind paying for the view.
lovely square. great place to stop eat, watch the world go by. In the square there are artists and market stalls. Really nice atmosphere, we would definatly go back there.

Beautiful. Beautiful place, with a lovely fountain. Loads of restaurants surrounding the Piazza to choose from, although you'll obvously pay more for these, than you would others that are just as good but without the view.Worth talking a walk to here if you are in the area.
Piazza Navona. This seems to be the meeting place for locals as they sip coffee and eat some of the incredible food on offer. when the bells chime here it's incredible and all eyes look up.
Great square. This is just one of those must see places in Rome. Don't be tempted to sit down and drink a coffee though. Ouch!!

Piazza Navona. I visited the Piazza Navona with family in April. We found it to be less crowded than some other piazzas, with a relaxed atmosphere and lovely photo opportunities. Most people visit to see the Fountain of the Four Rivers, but the other two smaller fountains are worth a quick look also. A must-see in Rome!
Beautiful!. Went here when it was raining but the Piazza is still stunning and beautiful. A very large square around the fountains.

Italian Elegance.. My wife and I visited Rome last July. It's an incredible city with many famous piazzas. The Piazza Navona is no exception as its beauty is clearly visible. The Italians clearly have a love for fountains. There are 3 in this long oval and symmetrically designed area. Bernini's Fountain of the Four Rivers, as well as an Egyptian obelisk, is the centerpiece set against a monumental church built by his rival, Borromini. This is one place were you could actually get lost taking pictures. As the sun was slowly setting and it begin to fill up with people, I lost my wife. It took about 40 minutes of pacing up and down the square before we finally found each other. The Piazza Navona is yet another one of Rome's many jewels.
My favorite piazza. Great restaurants and things to see in and around the piazza. I kept returning both in the daytime and the evenings.

Lively, but expensive if you eat there.. We found the Piazza Navona almost by accident and it is certaily a popular place with many painters and street artists plying their trade. We only stopped for a short time and had a drink, but looking around the many restaurants we found the prices to be rather higher than in other areas of Rome. A nice place to wander around, but I would recommend eating somewhere else.

Great place for people watching. A little off the beaten path, this piazza was a great place to enjoy a good meal, get some gelato, take in some history (it is built on top of an ancient stadium; part of which can be viewed), and a wonderful place to sit on a bench and watch people go by.

Three Fountains. visit here at nightime if you can the street artist are all around the fountains and as the trinket stalls, all along one side are the restaurants with the tables outside all with candles and lanterns lit ,the prices are steep but well worth it for the ambience
Lovely. Nice place, bustling with culture and people selling all manner of pieces of tat. Could sit and take it all in if you wished.

certainly one of the most beautiful places in rome. what a gorgeous piazza.so perfect. fantastic architectonical ensemble.the brazilian embassy a masterpiece, the fountain even nicer,the overwhelmingly pretty church ! what a jewel. not even one place in the whole of north america like that !
makes you proud of being european !
fantastic ! a must !

Baroque environment. The piazza has a baroque environment with beautiful (and famous) fountains and palazzi, but I think there are lots of other gems than Navona. I find the food & drinks overpriced and not high quality. Move past towards the Tiber and find hidden alleys, trattorias and excellent night life.

Typical ancient center--still alive today. I've visited Piazza Navona twice. Once about 30 years ago and the last time in September 2012. Nothing has changed, except the number of tourists. I saw it with a new perspective, the medieval buildings surrounding it, but it didn't seem to have the street artists and entertainment I recall. You do want to see this on any trip to Rome, even if briefly. It has romantic appeal, also for those interested in ancient architecture and culture.

Open area full of activity. I visited this place on a Saturday evening, it was full of great activities. On one side, there were several painters giving instant portraits of tourists, the other side was active with street shows. There were eateries all along the side. This place must have been used like a race track in the past, with it's oval shape. One must not miss some of the murals on the ceiling of the Brazil Embassy nearby.
a must see... This Piazza is one of the best areas to check out... Many places to eat and the vibe is fun and festive... Many artist and street preformers..

A cultural experience not to miss.... Piazza Navona was one of my favorite places in Rome. It was much larger than some of the other Piazzas we visited, and we missed some of the beauty of it the first time we visited. There are plenty of cafes and restaurants to sit outside and enjoy the people watching. The building architecture is beautiful to look at, and the fountains at night are gorgeous. Be sure to visit the piazza during the day and at night to get the full experience. Enjoy a nice glass of wine and enjoy the kids playing in the piazza. Such a romantic spot in Rome, I can't wait to return.

MY favorite Piazza in Rome!. This hidden piazza is very large. It was our favorite piazza to walk through. Very close proximity to the pantheon. Lots of cafes and places to sit and people watch. Also some beautiful churches to walk through. The fountains and huge and stunning. Overall a beautiful magical place!

It was so much nicer. I went to visit the Piazza after a break of 48 years. Things change and this was no exception. Admittedly this was in January but it was run down by comparison with 48 years ago. I have the photographs for then and now. Then it had a famous coffee restaurant serving iced coffees - now kit has two or three uninspiring restaurants. Having said that it is a must see square with three stunning fountains - it is just not as nice as it was.

Magical Piazza Navona. It's great. There's always something going on. It's interesting in the day and magical under the moonlight at night. And in the back streets behind the church that's on the Piazza has a lot of activity with resturants and bars. On Friday and Saturday nights all of Rome seems to be there.

An example of nice architecture. I think this is my favorite place in all Rome! This square is pretty big for an old square but it really is a place where you can spend some time, admiring the water fountains, watching the buildings or simply having something to eat at one of the numerous bars around the square. It s a colorful place full of Italian charm. It's worth visiting!

Beautiful but ........ Firstly let me say that the piazza navona is a beautiful beautiful place and a must see when in Rome, a great place to sit and enjoy a gelato while taking in the amazing architecture of the buildings and the three stunning fountains especially the fountain of four rivers. However thats if you don't mind being hassled by the sheer number of immigrants hassling you with their wares, you are unable to walk ten feet without one of them pushing a umbrella or a Pashmina scarf in your face, i have no problem with them selling their wares but some are very pushy, they kind of kill the charm of the piazza.

it has lost it's charm... I was there early January - and they had allowed that a fair be set up..which killed the aura of the piazza...food and all kind of nonsense is being sold there... a Relais Chateaux is nearby, Brazil's Embassy is on the Piazza...they must be upset

Definitely must see during Christmas time. I had the opportunity to see Piazza Navona this Christmas and I loved it. Around Christmas time the place is full of stands with sweets and Christmas decorations. There are lots of fun activities for kids and you can taste some traditional delicacies like ciambelle(big doughnut smeared with nutella or sprinkled with sugar) or porchetta sandwich (pork sandwich). If you're planning to visit Piazza Navona do it during Christmas time.

Piazza Navona...more like Nirvana!. After a long day of site seeing, there was nothing like a relaxing browse through the local artists and their work, a cool refreshment or dinner at one of the cafes or simply a leisurely visit with a glass of wine, enjoying the music. That doesn't even touch the beautiful architecture of the buildings, fountains and sculptures. We'll be back again!

Stunning piazza and Bernini's to boot. Amazing piazza that is built on a former stadium. The Bernini Fountains are beautiful here. There are artists and performers in the piazza to see and for as large as it is it was busy but quiet. Would definitely recommend making the trek to this piazza.

Piazza Navona at Night. Nighttime is the best time to visit (unless you are going to photograph). The piazza is full of artists and buskers and lined with cafes. Be advised that you will be charged a substantial sum just to sit down here, the fare is extremely expensive and not of the best quality, although there are a couple of decent restaurants.
nice. a hidden beauty of the clever architects .In a hidden place.A glory of the time, the old time, that no one can make in a now a days.

Nice area with seating. We wandered to see the fountain and ended up staying a few hours sitting on one of the benches watching the crowds and appreciating the buildings. Busy area and food not cheap as you would expect. 6euro a coke to me is a little too much.
Incredible Area. this was my 2nd favorite area of Rome after Trastevere, it has wonderful restaurants and really neat vibe and lots of Gelato choices

Christmas Magic. This is a wonderful place to wander any time of the year, but was truly magical at Christmas. The Piazza becomes a huge Christmas market with dozens of booths selling all kinds of crafts and food. Familes are out in droves and you can see the wonder of the holiday in the faces of the children. Here is the place to experience the magical thrill of Christmas.

Lovely lively piazza. Lively piazza lined with lovely little cafe's/ restaurants and artists selling their art. There are, if I remember correctly, three fountains in this piazza (one of them Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi) as well as a beautiful church (Sant' Agnese in Agone), definitely worth a wander round, loved the atmosphere here and there's also a place on the corner that sellsgreat gelato!

Great spot for lunch. This is a great spot for lunch and to people watch. We were there between Christmas and New Year's and there were so many booths that it made the fountain difficult to appreciate. I had been there seven years ago in the summer and enjoyed it better that time as I loved seeing all of the artists and their works.

The Montmartre of Rome. Loved this Piazza, beautiful architecture and fountains, and so many interesting things going on. I loved all the beautiful paintings, really good prices for such outstanding art. The artists are really friendly as well, and not pushy. (Kind of ironic since the people selling rubbish are SOOO pushy.)Possibly my favourite place in Rome, could've happily stayed there all day. Didn't try any of the cafes or restaurants though...maybe next time.Well-worth a visit.

Impressive artwork. This is a lovely little tucked-away square. It provides great photo opportunities at the fountains. I was really impressed with some of the paintings done by the artists in the square. They were really good and the prices were fair for such nice artwork, the detailing and everything was really cool.

One of my Favorite places. Whenever in Rome, I always end up in Piazza Navona. It's a great place to people watch, rest your tired feet, get some food and enjoy the art. I always tell people to go during the day and then again at night...it's two totally different places.During the day it's a lively art scene with artists displaying their work from pencil, to oils to watercolors. And you can watch them paint while you sip on some delicious wine.At night, the artists have all packed up and are gone and the square is filled with musicians, jugglers, people selling purses and bags, all while the locals do the evening passegiata. I love watching the couples and families take their evening stroll before they settle down for a nice meal.It's not where you want to go if you are looking for fine dining or AMAZING food but it's a delight to enjoy some time soaking up Italian life.

Good and bad. Dissapointed to see people selling cheap tat, the same as the Trevi fountain and the Spanish steps. However, it is really beautiful, with fountains and the church. I also was not put off by the artists, in fact we met a lovely man, called Enrico Sabia, who did a great caricature of me and my partner.

Piazza Navona has it all.. This beautiful piazza has it all. There are three fountains, the Fontana del Moro, the Fountain of Neptune, and the Fountain Four Rivers. There is also an obelisk and beautiful church, Sant'Agnese in Agone. It is also a great place to people watch. Grab a table at one of the restaurants in the square and enjoy the sights.

Must see. You must include this on your leisurely walk around Rome. Stop by the Pantheon, the Trevi Fountain and Piazza Novona. Make sure to see it at night and during the day. Truly not to be missed.

Worth a visit. Yes there are many hawkers and artists and souvenir shops, but that's all part of the atmosphere of the plaza. Nice way to kill time and watch the performances on display, or just mingle, or grab a bite to eat at the many cafes here.

Massive. Massive piazza with 3 beautiful fountains in the centre. In christmas time there is a christmas market there – plenty of stalls selling ornamets and knick knacks. There are also plenty of restaurants around the piazza, great atmosphere for the evening. One thing to note is that this piazza is abit cut off from the rest of the sights in rome (such as the fontana di trevi and colosseum) and there is also no Metro in this area. Closest metro is Spagna, in piazza di spagna – something to keep in mind.

Horribly commercial, it's like a fairground. The city of Rome must realise that this beautiful square is totally ruined by the overt commercialism of the market stalls and other traders. They could be put in any piazza, why ruin one of the most beautiful in the world ? Unless you can go at sunrise I wouldn't bother it's too awful.

Wow. This is one of my favorite spots in Rome. The piazza is littered with restaurants,shops,artist, and caricaturist. It is absolutely beautiful at sunset. If your looking for a fun way to spend the evening by yourself or with a special someone I would definitely recommend Piazza Navona.

A great place to people watch.... Again great place in Rome to visit, take your time to just sit and people watch...Nice cafes all around to just sit out have a coffee, glass of wine and relax, remember why your in Rome....

Great "market" and fountain. We stumbled upon this place when venturing further up from the Pantheon. The place is bustling with life even at night. The fountain looks great lighted up at night and there was a Christmas Market. My favorite was the carousel glistening in the night. More of a touristy place, with restaurants around and street entertainment.

Busy Piazza Always Worth A Visit. The Piazza Navona is always buzzing with activity. A visit to see the fountains, walking through Rome's narrow streets to find it, is a must. However, stay away from the overpriced, overrated tourist trap restaurants. The food is not good.
beautiful. Piazza Navona is a must place to visit while in Rome. Surrounded by shops and restaurants you have many options for food and coffee.

Great place to purchase artwork. We went to Piazza Navona and we had fun looking for oil paintings. We purchased a few oil paintings and took them back to the states to have them framed. The frame store we used back at home was amazed at the quality of the artwork. A nice piazza to take a stroll and look at the all of the items the venders have to offer.

Piazza Navona Christmas Market. We stopped in Piazza Navona upon arrival in Rome on the day after Christmas. The market was bustling with tourists, filled with vendor stalls, a carousel, and festive balloons. It was a great way to spend a little time while waiting to check into our hotel. As others have mentioned, it is touristy and a little junky, but we still had a great time experiencing the giant Nutella donuts and checking out the Befana ornaments and nativity scenes. Chestnuts were roasting as well.I'm not sure what the piazza is like without the Christmas market, as the appeal for us was primarily the holiday festivities. I'm rating a 4 for the Christmas market, but probably less on other days.

Beautiful but..... Piazza Navona is one of the most beautiful squares in Rome, but the traditional Christmas market is not what used to be. In the old days, throughout the month of December, you would see kiosks run by locals selling nativity scenes of all kinds and sizes, and the local Christmas sweets children eat during the holiday season. Now, the kiosks are noisy, full of second-rate, made in China stuff, stale food and are run by foreigners who do not understand what they are doing and why. Frankly, it makes me sad to see this tradition dead.

Better to visit outside of Xmas and New Year. Usually a lovely place to stroll around but at Xmas and New Year it is filled with stalls for the festive period and with the crowds it is not as good an experience but a fairly good atmosphere

Magical. It was raining lightly but the magic of this Piazza never ceases to astound me. The wonderful paintings and little stalls surrounding the amazing fountains and of the course the wonderful Chiesa that blew our minds: it is TRULY beautiful!

Christmas Stalls. We turned a corner and our eyes feasted on the most wonderful scene of Christmas stalls selling decorations and local sweets, carousels and fountains and happy smiling people. A really lovely place. The fountains are amazing, their sculptures awe inspiring.

A fountain to see with a lot of vendors there. What a great place to visit, simply a magnificent fountain and historical piece, but it is full of vendors who want to sell you any amount of garbage, they really need to clean this up as it ruins a great spectacle.

Lovely space, beautiful fountain. This square is lovely, and very interesting when you admire the space (not many people know that it is located in the open space of what once was a stadium built in 1st century AD). I read a lot of reviews talking about the Christmas market, and having seen it with and without the market, yes, I´ll admit it was much more enjoyable without it, but either way you can always admire its fountains, my favorite: Bernini´s “Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi”.

fun!. Oh how we love Piazza Navona! On weekends especially, there is always something going on. Markets, gypsies selling their wares, artists, musicians....it is just a great place to grab a beer (or a glass of wine) and people watch!

Christmas. During December the Piazza Navona is transformed into an outdoor carnival with a merry go round and lots of stalls offering games of chance and also a variety of purchasable gifts. Everything geared to the coming holiday.

Must Be Seen But Can Be Disappointing. The Piazza Navona is a highlight of Rome because of its Baroque architecture and Bernini sculpture -- there is nothing quite like it in the world. Yes, it's touristy, yes, it's crowded, and yes, watch your valuables, but still go for the overall beauty of the square. We found it enjoyable to wander among the art stands but particularly to watch the clever buskers. The greatest disappointment is that, unlike the nearby Fountain of Trevi, these beautiful fountains and church in the middle of the Piazza Navona are not brightly lit at night, for they would be much more impressive

Watch Out for your Wallet. Really amazing piazza. I would recommend grabbing a seat at an outdoor cafe and sipping a coffee while taking it all in. The pickpockets here are incredible and may even impress you!

Everyone say a "must" see in Rome...but.... We were at the Piazza Navona but all we saw was a Christmas holiday market with street entertainers! But did enjoyed the fountain and the structures of the buildings surrounding the square!

Lovely stop on our way to the pantheon. We walked through Piazza Navona and were very glad we got there during our short stay in Rome! There are some great photo's to be taken in this piazza obviously and it's certainly worth a walk though (we didn't eat here). The shops nearby were a bit pricey for souvineers though!

Skip It, at least at Christmas Time. We had visions of a classy Christmas market full of artisan merchandise and appropriately decorated for Christmas. What we found was cheap and tacky junk and a carnival sideshow. What a disappointment.

Disappointing. We had been advised that this was a 'must see' highlight of Rome. However when we visited at New Year the Piazza contained a tacky Christmas market which obscured it somewhat. Great restaurants to be found in the streets surrounding the square.

Don't leave Rome without seeing Piazza Navona!. This is my favorite Piazza in Rome for multiple reasons: architecture, food and crowd. I can just spend hours here sitting in the piazza watching people walk by, eating my chocolate tartufo and stare at the amazing fountains al night long! We went during the Christmas holiday so there was a bazaar going on selling all multitude of stuff from toys to food. This is the famous piazza that Julia Roberts ate her gelato so if you want to re-live such scene, this is the place to be. There's a restaurant close by called La Focaccia on Via del Pacce and it was just a complete combination to cap the night of an amazing time in Rome!

Nice fountains - but busy and better places to visit.. The fountains were huge and (of course) beautiful but these are everywhere in Rome. We went during the holidays so there was a Christmas Market and it made it very crowded and most of the stuff for sale was over priced - better deals and stuff found elsewhere.
Nice stop. Piazza Navona is really nice place to stop for a short while. In the summer it is filled with locals everywhere available either selling their art or able to sketch a portrait.
Great spot to sit relax eat. Great spot to have something to eat and people watch however beware of pedlars trying to take you down back streets to sell you expensive but genuine fake Pravda bags!!
Exciting Experience. Great old piazza that contains many vendors, a fine church and is surrounded by endless streets filled with shops and restaurants of every type.Is great fun, an must visit.
Excellent. A surprise - we really enjoyed walking around taking in the sights and exploring the tourist stalls really worth a visit

Must Sees in Roma. The Piazza was transformed into a gigantic marketplace for Christmas with endless kiosks of food and all kinds of crazy items. he smell from roasting chestnuts and fresh donuts was amazing. The downside was that you could not truly enjoy the fabulous fountain because it was so packed with vendors and shoppers.

Big but hardly beautiful. This lovely long rectangular square is littered with stalls of touristy gifts,hawkers and traders.Some OK cafes around the edge for watching the people drift by.fairly traffic free too , but keep moving folks it is one to pass through and tick off your list of Squares I have visited.nice buildings around the square ,busy lively and easily accessibleIt will not linger in your memories.
Christmas Markets?. Don't bother - this was like sideshow alley at a fair... Maybe the Northern Italian markets are better... but perhaps this is just not as big a tradition as in Germany?
Very Atmospheric. The Xmas markets were on as it was December. Good place to stop for a refreshment break after the Forum

Stimulus Satiation. Terrible carnival neon lighted booths with cheeps china crap sold. There are some fine food booths worth a visit. The whole place was overloaded with crap selling e.g. fake bags, fake silk scarfs an so on...

Christmas Navona. Chrismas Navona is a sight. Packed with all things Chritmas. Mostly, you will find candy, la befana (the epiphany witch), tons of nativity parts, and lots of kids. Great way to get into the Christmas spirit. Oh, and hit the food stand on the southwest corner for a €1,00 cup of wine! Ha! Only in Rome...

An oasis at the centre of Rome. After 19:00 when there's no sun and people just walk among the streets of Rome, piazza Navona is like a hidden treasure!!Its a wonderful match of Bernini's baroque fountains and all these young and old artists who paint around the square, as the art pass through the age. For me the best place for a night walk,better than Fontana di trevi beacause its an open place and you can feel more comfortable and you can see the striking status of fountains. Better not to eat there, nice but a little more expensive
nice place. piazza navona is a superb place in rome. it is full of italy style.i highly recomend to visit this beautiful place

Terrific, beautiful, really large. Every city should have a Piazza like this, jst so beautiful ....pedestrian safe social meeting place. Please take notice Sydney City Council! Great Christmas markets.....delicious treats!
Great Christmas market. The stalls selling every conceivable item necessary for a Nativity scene are extraordinary, as is the variety of candy available for a visit from La Bufana on Jan. 6.

Better to visit the Cathedral of Agnes. This square has 3 fountains. In front of the main one, there is beautiful cathedral, you must visit inside of it! So, so beautiful. I could feel the "madness of genious artist". the most wonderful place I have ever visited. the story of 2 architects makes me more interested in the reason why they created these wonders.

Navona in Christmas. I visited Rome in December and so, when I went to Piazza Navona, there was a Christmas Fair in the piazza. It was nice once that's not something you'll find there any time and you get italian christmas spirit but it came out to be difficult to actually see the Piazza and everything it has to offer.The Fair had a carousel, lots of fair stalls only selling christmas ornaments and Nativity Scene pieces. It was very inspiring. Jugglers and apples of love, cottoncandy, there was everything that could fit in the place.The sea of people attending the fair and the stalls unfortunately prevented a lot to see has I wished the beautiful fountain of Bernini that is in the middle of the square and it was almost impossible to visit the Church Sant'Agnese in AgoneThe piazza still have the shape of an old Stadium, since it was the Domician Stadium, and is surrounded by buildings, that were built over the benches. The buildings and small streets that gives you access to the piazza gives you the feeling that it turns out to be a big but somehow reserved place to be and all around there is restaurants with esplanades where you can sit and enjoy the space.I enjoyed to visit Piazza Navona with this Christmas Fair, that seemed to me that takes place every year by this time, but I also wished that I could see it more unfettered. I believe that the perception of the space, its history and art works would be much much different.

Take the Time to Appreciate it. We were rushed through the Piazza Navona on a walking tour through the ancient centre, and by the time we wound ourselves past the fountains, other tourists, countless artist stalls and of course, the ubiquitous splat ball vendors, all the time with the blinding morning sun in our faces, I felt like we missed it. It’s more than just a rectangular square, with a few fountains in it. Give yourself some time there to appreciate the Baroque architecture and soak up the atmosphere. And while the cafes and restaurants on the Piazza will do more damage to your wallet than the pickpockets, I think it’s probably worth digging deep just once for the experience. Whether you take a walking tour, guide book, or quick look at Wikipedia before you go, make sure you educate yourself about the Piazza. Otherwise, you’ll miss out. Believe me.

Circus. Yes, it is actually a former Roman circus of Cesar Domitian (the excavation may be visited upon arrangements) and the shape was preserved in the form of this long square. At present there are beautiful barocco fountains (the most important is Bernini's Four Rivers) oppposite beautiful St Agnes' church by his rival Borromini). A vivid meeting point, cafes, street artists, music.

Christmas market in Rome.. Went to see the Christmas market, and it is not the scale one would see in Germany. The items carried and the stalls were few in comparison to Austria or Germany. Having seen the other Christmas market this was not worth the time.

Always worth a visit. Lovely Christmas market. Full of ornaments and Christmas bits and pieces. Of course the fountains are absolutely amazing!!!!!!! Don't miss wandering around the side streets for a bit of atmosphere, a coffee or a glass of vino ;)

Great amosphere. We visited the Piazza Navona in December when the Christmas fair was on, there was a lovely familty atmosphere and it was very busy. Would like to go back and visit when the weathers warmer
A wonderful busy Paizza. Loads to see and great cafes to enjoy a wine in whilst watching the shoppers go by The imposing amazing Del Quattro fountain in the centre.

Amazing!! Don't miss the tartufo at Tre Scalini. This was a pretty neat area to walk around. Being there the 2nd week of December allowed us to be able to see some of the Christmas markets that are set up. They aren't the best Christmas markets as some of the items seem a little cheesy, but it was nice to look around to say the least. We only spent about 20 minutes there, kind of wandering around. You have to have the tartufo at Tre Scalini no matter what!! It's a couple of euros, but soooo worth it. I think I liked it better than the gelato! Even if it's cold outside, you have to try it. We also tried some of the roasted chestnuts from one of the vendors, but it wasn't my favorite. It's a neat thing to try and you can get about 5-6 chestnuts for about 2 euros. Once again, this is a neat little place to walk through, but don't spend much time here. There are other places worth your time.

2ND TO TREVI FOUNTAIN. Another beautifull fountain in the city of fountains . Many artists around . Enjoy your time and relax . Pictured in ANGELS AND DEMONS (THE MOVIE) . A must only if you are in rome for four days but not less .

Loved it!. Was very nice to just walk around and checkout all the vendors, plenty of artists set up as well. Watching one of the older men water paint the Colosseum in such detail we sort of got sucked into buying a couple of his fantastic paintings. Very nice gelato place on the north end of Navona, grab some and have a seat near one of the fountains and just take it in.

Loved it. . .. We walked over from our hotel. Enjoyed the afternoon sitting in one of the restaurants, enjoying a lazy afternoon people watching. There are artist selling their paintings and a few shops selling leather goods. A must see. .

Lovelly for a stroll and an ice cream. The square is very beautiful, has a nice fountain and has tons of artists selling paintings etc. We spend a lovely hour there just walking around, got an ice cream and enjoyed the atmosphere. I would not recommend buying anything in the bars/restaurants even for Rome the prices are stupid.

A must visit piazza. The elongated Piazza Navone owes its shape to the first century Circus Agonolis over which it is built, the stadium built by the Emperor Domitian and the foundations of which can be viewed well below street level over a railing in one of the adjacent streets.At each end of the Piazza are 16th century fountains, the Moors Fountain and the Fountain of Neptune, while in the centre is Berninis famous 17th century Four Rivers Fountain sculpted around a central obelisk that depicts the four great rivers of the world as known at the time the fountain was commissioned.Opposite the central fountain is the beautiful Baroque Church Sant Agnese in Agone that was rebuilt by the architect Borromini in the seventeenth century,sponsored by Pope Innocent X.The Piazza attracts vendors, artists, and entertainers and has street cafes that as would be expected of such a popular place are not cheap.A must visit Rome attraction.

very touristy but gorgeous. Don't eat in a restaurant in the actual piazza; the food will be lackluster and the cost ridiculous. However, do wander around the fountains and take in the beautiful architecture. There IS some amazing gelato at the north end of the piazza.

Disappointed. Yes, it's a fabulous piazza with a glorious fountain and stunning St. Agnes church. But there is no enjoyment in the constant bombardment by vendors and seeing almost the entire plazza overrun with stalls. We went in the evening so maybe its different during the day. No place to stop to just look, absorb and enjoy. We were glad to have seen it again, and equally glad to escape to a less touristy part of the city.

Lovely big space, with Christmas market in full swing!. This is a lovely long square (or a rectangle if you are being quadrilaterally correct!) Filled with Christmas market stalls, lots going on, we had a look round it a couple of times.There is a toy shop at one end that had the biggest polar bear stuffed toy that I had ever seen in a christmasy window display (they had 3 window displays, they were all excellent). One of the stalls was selling massive donuts (massive!) covered in nutella, we didn't have one but they looked original! There were a few stalls selling miniatures figurines and nativity scenes these were most enchanting and we did buy a couple of them as momentos!

One of the great piazzas of the world. Built on the ruins of the ancient Domitian Stadium and is enormous. It is like a great theater of beautiful buildings, cafes, spectacular fountains and the flow of people. It is full of tourists, people trying to sell you things, mimes, etc., but it is still magnificent and is particularly magical at dusk when the swallows form murmurations overhead.

St Agnes Church rivals Saint Peters and is free and uncrowded. This innocuous and almost hidden church on the side near the magnificent Four Rivers fountain rivals the famous St Peters Basilica. From the outside t looks almost like a public building and is not immediately recognisable as a church. However, walk up the stairs, open the two separate doorways that look like they are closed, enter and be literally spellbound by the three dimensional sculptures embedded into the walls and ceilings, the elaborate decoration and the magnificent paintings. And ts all free.
Great Piazza - Great Times. This Piazza has a lot to offer. Lots of yummy restaurants and street vendors. Great place to relax and hang out.
Great spot. We happened to walk through and loved this place. There are a few great restaurants around the piazza to have some wine, great food, and people watch. Highly recommended.
The best one. This is the best Piazza in Rome, there is an awesome vibe to it and it has the most beautiful fountains, it is a great place to hang out.

Navona. We went there every day while in Rome. Love the colorful buildings surrounding the fountains. Bought paintings and pottery. Relaxed eating and watching the people in the square. Entertainment comes out at sunset.

Go for Bernini Statues and coffee on the sidewalk!. Beautiful piazza with artists selling their wares. You walk a lot in Rome and this was a great place to sit in an outdoor cafe and watch people go by and to look at some of the most lovely statues. Bought lovely pottery made in italy in one of the shops there.

Shop, eat, relax, admire. One of the places you must go to. The three fountains are worth seeing and the piazza has a sort of fair with market stalls and casual places to eat.in nd very close to the piazza are four churches that have the top rating in the Michelin guide.
Fountain in Rome.... What to say more that it's another impressive fountain in Rome. One more within a nice place and with nice surrounding

Fabulous. It is the place to be. Lots of restaurants to dine al fresco and watch the world go by. We had a good lunch, followed by a Nutella crepe and did some shopping. I think Rome is the home of Nutella!

Saturday afternoon market with added helicoptors!. had a wonderful visit to the beautiful Piazza Navona however sadly it was a little ruined with all the market sellers and when i say market sellers i mean tat and rubbish sellers. its such a beautiful place but you had to fight your way through all the street sellers trying to sell your rubbish. resturants here had great food but a little pricey but hey thats Rome. if you want cheap go to Crawley!despite the above mentioned its still worth a visit, i just wish we didnt have all the street sellers and insisant helicopters constantly flying above our heads. there was a march on so its understandable! loads of coppers too but you did feel safe. go figure.....

Everything you can want out of a Piazza. and more. This was my first time in Rome during the holiday season and staying at a hotel on the Piazza was perfect. The Christmas market was just what I needed to kick off Christmas time.

great place to just enjoy the moment. The fountains here are really interesting and the rest of the piazza it filled with street sellers and performers. We enjoyed the beautiful day and setting by picking out one of the restaurants and splitting a half bottle of wine. Getting an actual meal at the restaurants will set you back a bit but the bottle of wine was only 10E and we had such an enjoyable time. I'd recommend the same to anyone who's looking for a nice way to just sit back, people watch, and enjoy the amazing city you're in.
Lovely. Great ice cream, loads of eateries. Beautiful water fountains and atmosphere. Stumbled across this piazza, and glad we did!

Shame about the restaurants. We were there at lunchtime and instead of being able to appreciate the piazza were bombarded by restaurants on the piazza trying to sell us lunch or food and were thus unable to enjoy or appreciate the piazza for what it is historically, such a great shame.

The perfect place to stay. We were lucky enough to stay on the plaza this trip (Relais Navona - great little b&b) and the Christmas markets were just starting. Just a beautiful place full of people and life all the time.
Waw. I liked this historique place lot of people take pic so Nice And very cool place i lové it ils a place to visit

Artists, fountains, Rome at its best!. This was the meeting point for a group of us who were off doing out thing. I spent a few hours just lingering by the Four Rivers fountain, watching the artists peddle their work and lovers and families enjoying a day in the Italian sun. This was sooo much more enjoyable than Trevi fountain, which was nearly impossible to see with all the people.
Fun place.. Worth it just to sit and people watch. Be careful of thieves, however. And the side streets of the piazza are loaded with great little shops.

Must see. Very lively place, where you can find both locals and tourists. Lots of artists, painters, entertainers and vendors of suspicious souvenirs. At night lots of people at the square and it's best to go in early morning to avoid the crowds. The surrounding restaurants are a little expensive, but worth the enjoyment of Italian dishes on this beautiful square.

Great big long Piazza with amazing fountains. Great fountains here from Michael Angelo and Bernini, go to see and photograph them. The cafes around are overpriced and a bit aggressive. Night life is more of the same but worth doing at least once. We enjoyed the art exhibits on the weekend.
The warmth and energy of Rome. A beautiful place, filled with the warmth and energy of the eternal city. The Bernini Fountain of the Rivers is amazing!

Tourist must see!. This is a beautiful and large piazza with impressive views on all sides. We saw it during the day and also sat there in the evening at one of the wine bars. There are paintings and pictures for sale. Most are mass produced and the vendors are not the artists. We picked a wine bar on the plaza. The view was great but the wine was not. Not to be missed when in Rome. The people watching is fantastic.

Beautiful piazza with fountains. We came here early one morning before there were many tourists around and while the restaurants were still closed. It was great to see the Four Rivers fountain.When we walked through again later at night it was very crowded and full of people trying to sell souvenirs and we couldn't see the view of the fountain was not so good because it is not lit up very well. It was much nicer when it was quiet.

Not what it used to be. I have been to this square more than on e over the years. While I still love he fountains and would still recommend you go if you have never been, I am disappointed at how it looks now. I remember when it was just a square with many cafes around. Now they have all these stand with things for sale. I would almost be ok with it if it was local goods, but honestly 80% of it just seemed like cheap stuff not worth looking at. I hope they rethink the decision to have so many vendors there and return this square to the beautiful place it once was.

Spoilt by the hundreds of immigrant beggars. What would be a scenic pleasant place to set and explore is spoilt by the hoards of beggars selling their tat from umbrellas to pashminas and tripods of all things. Really feel the area should be policed more since the caribinieri will fine a tourist for purchasing this tat. They are intimidating and rude and spoil what could be a relaxing experience in a very beautiful square

What a wonderful afternoon. We walked through the Piazza and when it started to rain, ducked into one of the many restaurants lining the outside of the plaza. It was wonderful and so nice to see the many artists in the middle. The food here is a little price but the atmosphere makes it totally worth it.

Every time there!. It is always nice to visit Piazza Navona although the restaurants are not cheap. It was good that the Rome police kept an eye on illegal sellars. Nice place also late in the autumn.
disapointed :(. food ... kind of ok ...service .. slow and ... almost not seeing you ...clean .. with okish wine ...

good spot to chill. The dinig outelts in piazza are quite expensive and can have a limited view, depending on what temp market stalls are up or down! At the northern entrance is a good spot where prices are more reasonable and the southerly tables have a good view
Where am I? Pakistan.... Well its well known fact that cities like Rome are full of foreign immigrants...but OMG. Pakistans, Indians, Gypsy...Fountains are great, palace as well but...
Nice people watching stop. Not so much of a destination (unless you want to stop for gelato or dinner), but a nice place to stop, watch people and enjoy the two amazing fountains in the Piazza.
what a delight!. Must visit, food, leisure, culture- its a lovely little spot to relax by the fountains or have some gelato in the sun.

A pretty square spoilt by hawkers. Piazza Navona is one of the main tourist hot spots of Rome with far too many foreign (African?) touts dodging the local police and other so called artists selling ghastly paintings. lots of reastaurants mostly very expensive but having said all that it is worth visiting (it free) and the fountains are splendidly baroque. i have had lunch there more than once over the years so it can't be too bad. you can use the toilets in the restaurants.
The best piazza in Rome. The 3 fontanas is the symber of water. It is surrounding by noce shopping complex... really an enjoyable place to spend afternoon

great area. Terrific piazza to wander through especially late afternoon/dusk. Berninis fountain is beautiful as are the other 2. There are sooo many artists who have art in varied mediums, but we were not hassled to buy which was refreshing plenty of restaurants to sit and watch the world go by.
Great food! Great sights!. We spent more time here than at any other place during our stay. Highly recommend eating at Zio Firo restaurant then around the corner to the Frigidarium for gelatto.

Lovely Ice cream shop!. We stumbled upon this while trying to find The Pantheon and Trevi Fountain... Beautiful Piazza! Lovely fountains and really yummy ice cream shop. We wandered around eating our gelato feeling very Italian :) in the fading light of day....

So much to see in this 'not to be missed' attraction. A very pretty and busy piazza full of artists selling pictures of Rome and other subjectsl - three fountains and an extremely impressive church. We had a very pleasant lunch at one of the many pavement restaurants (Menu Touristico) that included bruschetta, pasta and a glass of wine for 15 Euros. Avoid the guided tour and stroll around at your leisure.

Piazza Navona.. I visited many of the piazzas while I was in Rome. There are so many in Rome you could literally waste your entire time trying to navigate around the city looking for all of them and get lost in the process. If nothing else.....this is the only piazza you should visit. Hear me out.....in my opinion, this is how Italy should be if you wanted to mix the history and rich tradition of Italy. The piazza is surrounded by many restaurants and artists painting and drawing trying to capture the essence of Piazza Navona that can not actually be caught. You have to go there yourself to see what it is all about. The Fountain of the Four Rivers was a sight to behold. The fountain is an amazing piece of art itself and in my opinion only being out matched by the mighty famous Trevi Fountain. There are a few other fountains to see as well and it is a great place to take a picture and capture what Rome and Italy is all about.

Piazza Navona. I'm glad that we got to see the Piazza Navona, but other than being able to say we were there, it was very crowded and the sidewalk restaurants, although abundant, were very expensive. The fountain of the four rivers is beautiful and the focal point of the Piazza.

Really Crowded. There were soooooooo many tourist here, all the time, that it was a pain to walk through. We stayed near by, so got to see it daily and it was always completely full of people. Walk throught it very early or very late. Once through is all you need.

If visiting the Italian Piazza - must walk through Navona. One of the famous fountains also known as "Fountain of Four Rivers by Bernini is here and it was gorgeous. This piazza was built on the Stadium of Domitian (Circus Agonalis) and is also wonderful city market for paintings, etc.
Romantic!. If you go to Rome you can´t miss Piazza Navona, it´s surrounded by restaurants and in the middle there´s an amazing fountain: Bernini´s 4 rivers, just beautiful!
Great place. Great place . So vibrant and colourful. Lots of very good places to eat in . Visit the church of St Agnes.

Beautiful, elegant square. This square was elegant and uncrowded in contrast to la piazza di spagna or la piazza di trevi. It is surrounded by lots of restaurants and cafes and a lovely fountain in the centre.

Much changed. Returned to Rome after a few years and stayed near Piazza Navona.
