Italians prefer not to sit, evidently. Okay, the Piazza is a stunner and Bernini's fountain is a must-marvel at, but really, couldn't the Romans provide a few more benches for us foot-sore travelers? Sitting on the rim of the fountain is not permitted, although we and a few dozen others tried it until shooed away by the carabinari. To sit and admire, go to Paris.

Huge Piazza!. We found ourselves at Piazza Navona after a few hours of walking the cobblestone streets of Rome; and it was a great place to visit.
While there, we sat down for a quick caricature drawing of the two of us; nice time spent at this Piazza.

Magnificent church, obelisk, fountains! Best seen before sunset.. I really loved Piazza Navona. I think it might be the longest piazza in Rome. The 17th-century Baroque church Sant'Agnese in Agone is a beautiful edifice. The fountains are amazing, particularly Bernini’s Fountain of the Four Rivers which also features an Egyptian obelisk (notice the sculpture of Rio de la Plata River cowering as if the facade of the church could crumble against him). For me, the best time to visit is around sunset (Sant'Agnese is not well lit at night).

I love this place.. As day progresses this piazza fills with tour groups soaking up history and street 'artists' touting their wares. Arrive early in the morning to enjoy the expanse of this space, to see the restos just setting up, to feel that you are enjoying this all by yourself, and not surrounded by hoards of sightseers.
Spectacular!. We loved it, has fantastic fountains, good cafes, live music and lovely setting all around.

Utterly brilliant. This was number one on my list for Rome, it really is brilliant. A hugh open space in the middle of a crowded city Piazza Navona best defines my Rome experience. The fountain of the four rivers by Bernini stands in the middle and is breathtaking, words fail to best describe it you need to see it yourself. Although we were there in Summer the is Christmas Market that would stunningto see also.

A beautiful square. You can chill with a dessert or a drink and take in the views. The fountains are beautiful. Walk around the square and you can buy a fake bag or buy a painting or a picture from the many artists who set up their stall there. Not as buy as Fontana Di Trevi.
A beutiful place. I just love Piazza Navona, great to have a tartufo at Tre Scalini and enjoy watching all the people.
very interesting to say the least. exciting, not enough time to see everything, make sure u have walking shoes, sneakers.
Busy but beautiful. Full of cafe's and restaurant and street performers. Enjoy, sit and watch the world go by with a gorgeous ice cream.
lovely piazza. lovely piazza to have an ice cream in. Resaurants are expensive here, but just head off down one of the other streets to find lovely cheap restaurants
Turistic, but nice. many restaurantes around the piazza. nice to wonder around.
To die for!. the most beautiful rectangle Piazza with the fountain depicting the 4 rivers. Gorgeous cafes allign the sides.

most popular place in rome. there is always fun, all day and all night
restaraunts are very expensive

Piazza Navona - A bustling place. Piazza Navona is one of those places you keep finding again and again as you wander about the centro storico of Rome. It is such a large Piazza that it has three fountains - each with wonderful sculptures. The play of light on the white marble and the water is just lovely together with the sound of the water. The pigeons think it is wonderful for a drink or a bath. The Piazza is always busy - tourists find wonderful photo opportunities and people watch while eating some wonderful gelati from the gelateria on the Corso Emanuele end of the Piazza (get the dark chocolate).Mime actors abound - I feel sorry for the Egyptian mummies - they must get so hot and they cant prevent anyone taking their photograph and not give them anything! Dirty pool that! Later in the evening the musicians and bands come out making a very festive air. In the centre are the artists. As one poster said some are clearly just copy artists while others are a joy to watch creating a new perspective. The cartoonists will whip up a caracature in no time and some of them are very good. I will post a photograph of one. Unfortunately there are also the fake bag, fake pashmina shawl and scarves sellers. I do feel sorry for them as this the only way they can make money to live.Return to Piazza Navona at different times of the day and experience the changing scene. Avoid the expensive restaurants around and walk a couple of streets away for something more reasonable.

Day and night. This is another piazza that one should visit both by day and by night. It offers splendid architecture, as well as a variety of buskers - human statues, singers, comedians, artists. It is such a large piazza, that I never felt constricted by the crowds. Rather, it offered a lovely atmosphere on a warm summer's night.

Nice Fountains. The legent says that the romans use to close the Piazza with movable walls, flood it and stage naval battles in it.. i wasn't there so i cannot confirm. but is nice to know that every corner of Rome has hidden history..
Great Piazza. A classic piazza with many artisists selling their work. Tons of outdoor dining and drinking and well worth a visit. Very good for people watching.
What a sight!. It isn't just the Piazza, the fountains or the architecture. The people here, the music, the art, the food are the real sights.
Visit after dark. We got here late in the evening and it was buzzing. The fountain of rivers with all its comic insults is brilliant.
Good place to visit. Enjoy this place and all amenities around. Nice places to eat and walk. Enjoyed the gelato offered in one little place that I don't remember the name

Simply Stunning!. Beautiful, beautiful "square". The fountains are great, ambiance is great, lots of artists and artwork to buy. Again surrounded by trattorias, stunning architecture and gelato! Unmissable!
bright and lovely. this fountain and piazza was lovely, with the artists all over showing their wares. A nice stop for a vino and a meal.
Not to be missed. probably the most beautfiful square - or rather oval - in the world. Don't miss it.

The Scaffolding Is Off!. All cleaned and spiffy the fountain is again a beauty to behold. We avoid the over-priced restaurants on the perimiter but the vendors selling their art works and sketches are fun to see and the prices seemed almost bargain-like compared to everything else in Rome.
The real center of Rome. The atmosphere here on the Piazza Navona is just unique. You can just sit by the Bernini fountain or visit the cafes and have " bella vita "!
Italy at it's finest.. A typical italian Piazza but not to be missed. Try to go at a early before the crowds gather.

a great place to take a walk. Enjoy walking in this beautiful piazza, just becareful of the so called artest most of them have the same copies of the same painting which is clearly printed, some real artest paint on the spot and you can see original work as well. There are many restaurants around and you can take a carage ride as well, or you can simply buy a bottle of wine, some cheese and bread and sit on one of the many benches while enjoying the views of the beautiful fountains the huge church or the many tourist and locals passing by.
lively. All artists , or most of them are here. Go for a meal or a drink, sit ,relax and people watch.
Fun place. Good location. Lots of artworkandmusicians. Great place with lots of outdoor cafes. Very pretty at night
the most lovely piazza. claen and vibrant, buzzing day and night with super food and gelati

By Day or By Night. The quintessential Italian piazza is fun by day but even better by night. Lots of cafes, artists and performers and tons of shopping make for a great time. Be sure to explore the little side streets in every direction from here.

Fantastic Piazza. You can spend the day here enjoying the incredible history as well as enjoying a nice meal or drink (pricey though). It has the most wonderful atmosphere with street entertainers and artists and of course the street vendors! It all adds to the mix and is well worth spending some time there. It is also very near the river so it is lovely to have a wander around the area.
The best. If you go here, go to Tre Scallini for the tartufo - AMAZING! The Piazza is beautiful.
Lovely Piazza to Stumble Across. Lovely picturesque piazza that ouses charm. Fantastic Gelataria nearby and is within easy reach of other Roman sites of interest. Worth a meander around this place!
Nice place. Nice place to go! It is quite big.. and nice restaurants to find if you have a walk in small streets.

Packed and Crowded!. It was a nice sunday morning with the crowds, but it got very overwhelming when every place was flooded with people (not sure if it was mainly tourists or mixed with locals) It was hard to enjoy anything when it was hard to walk around.
Great hangout spot. Loved the fountains, restaurants and shops around the square. Great impromtu performers.
Beautiful and lively square. Had lunch in the Piazza Navoona. Love visiting it every time we are in Rome. Great people watching (even though there isn't a great restaurant on it).
Sheila C. Very lively place and we had a very good meal here while watching the world go by.
Really fun. Good food, good entertainment, beautiful fountains, and don't miss St Agnes's Church. It's very lovely.
Busy and beautiful. Piazza Navona is the place to be on a warm evening if you appreciate a crowded, busy, but still very beautiful square. Not surprisingly nicknamed "Rome's living room".
Nice place to see painters, artists, etc. You can have a lot of fun here and by nice artworks.
Navona. Historical but too geared for tourist. Restuarant off the main piazza were very good.
Drink It In. Loved just strolling round this area. Lots to catch the eye amongst the street artist stalls, and plenty of choice for a coffee or drink.
Fountains and expensive restaurants. Very atractive and lively, with artists, restaurants, embassies, but obviously tourist chic - lovely narrow cobbled streets around it,.

One of the most famous Roman Piazza's. Everyone loves Piazza Navona, for the fountains, the setting, the outdoor restaurants, and the art for sale here. Luckily we've visited Rome and the beautiful Piazza Navona several times before, as on the Sunday afternoon we vistied in Octoboer it was so crowded you could barely move. I would think a weekday or early morning visit would prove less crowded, and provide you a chance to better experience the beauty of Piazza Navona.

just a quick peek. this was a stop on our evening city tour, very quick but you got the idea. the restaurants that over looked it were busy. would like to go back again during the day for a longer view

Lovvely lively place. We absolutly loved this plaza. We ate at "Tucci" and had a fabulous meal and there is so much to see and so fun to people watch...we went in April and had gorgeous weather so we could hang out all night long. Very romantic!

One of the nicest piazzas. Lots of little shows and restaurants. Don't advise eating in anyone of these places. Go outside the piazza for better deals. Campo de Fiori had better meal deLs and service and we weren't charged any service fees.
Lively!. Piazza Navona is an excellent place to stop for lunch or a drink and watch the world go by!
Come and relax. Surrounded by lovely cafes and restaurants, you can sit and watch the world go by, the fountains and the street entertainment. Stop rushing around and relax for a while here.
Quintessential Roma!. Grab a pizza and some wine at Tucci - very friendly waiters and the people watching here is like nowhere else in the world.

Wonderful place. We stayed in an apt. right on the piazza and it was wonderful. I really enjoyed sitting , walking around the piazza people watching, admiring the street performers, art, the fountains, and feeling the excitement of the crowds visiting. Yes it is very touristy but worth at least a visit.
touristy but nice. it was quite busy and lots of artists displaying their work; "ignoring" them, the scene is great- a huge area, beautiful fountain and surroungings of the piazza

Sunny afternoon sipping wine and marvelling at the scenery life doesn't get any better. My title sums it up. Spent one glorious afternoon sipping wine and having some wonderful cuisine at the Piazza Navona. Between the beautiful views, the wine, food, warm dayand everyone obviously enjoying themselves, this was an afternoon not soon to be forgotten!

Beautiful but overcrowded. Perhaps the most beautiful Piazza of Rome, with the characteristic shape, but very crowded, with lots and lots of tourists, as well as artists (painters especially), caffes and illegal sellers, who ruin the true spirit of this wonderful place. Of course, if you like that kind of noisy and full-of-life places, you will enjoy yourselves. Discover the narrow streets west of the Piazza, which are full of little bars and caffes, reminding a little bit of Trastevere. I would recommend to comvine your visit to Navona with a previous stop at Pantheon and a later at Campo dei Fiori.

Lively, entertaining, energetic, fun square in Roma. I wish we had stayed within a few minutes walk of this square. We ate here twice and enjoyed the live music, art for sale, and the great people watching. This was our favorite Piazza in Rome.

Don't forget the gelati. We followed a crowd with rainbow banners, but couldn't understand the Italian. A concert was being held at one end of Piazza Navona, and some sidestreets were closed off for the event. Unfortunately, not completely relaxing on the day!

Very touristy. Piazza Navona is a large space that follows the shape of an ancient stadium. It has three fountains, with the one in the center being very impressive (Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi or "Fountain of the Four Rivers by Gianlorenzo Bernini for Pope Innocent X). This central fountain has sculptures that represent the 4 main rivers 4 continents (Nile, Danube, Ganges and Plate). The fountains are definitely worth the visit; however, much of the rest of the Piazza has very touristy restaurants with tourist rather than traditional menus. During the day are many artists selling their works (or prints of other peoples'), although it certainly isn't as good as Montmartre. In the evening the area was full of tourists so possiblybest to avoid.

Most romantic morning in Rome. Sitting at the Piazza Navona at a cafe and sipping prosecco with my husband was one of my favorite moments in my trip to Italy. It's well worth the extra euro you will pay to be at a tourist cafe. Linger for more than an hour, watch the street performers, munch on a snack, listen to the gurgling fountains and be amazed by the statues. We strolled the piazza and bought a beautiful original sketching. Don't miss the piazza navona for a relaxing, romantic break from sight seeing!

Sublime. This is the single most beautiful public space in the world. Bernini's Four Rivers fountain is one of the greatest outdoor sculptures in existence (look carefully at the horse), and the Sainte Agnese church is a something outstanding.
Lovely, day or night. The piazza and sculptures/fountains are very beautiful and the local artists selling their wares added to the charm. Nice place to relax.

Fun way to pass some time at night. Bernini's Four River's sculpture (amazing), performers, artist stands, cafes for a glass of wine, and good people watching. We enjoyed both our walks through Piazza Navona. Don't miss the two other fountains in the Piazza -- at the north and south ends -- worth a few minutes.

Just sit, rest and eat. After we visited the Colosseum and the Vittorio Emanuelle Monument, we went to Piazza Navona before continuing our trip to the Pantheon, Trevi Fountain and the Spanish Steps. Piazza Navona was the perfect place to rest! we ate in one of the restaurants, saw the beautiful fountains, did some people-watching, and after lunch.. Ice Cream!

Fun place to people watch. Enjoyed seeing the architecture, strooling through and seeing the artists' work and - nto to be missed - gettng Gelato at Tre Scalini. We ahd lunch there and then got gelato fromthe little shop they so we could stroll and enjoy the gelato. It was soo good we walked over (from the termini area) another day just to get more gelato.
Cannot miss it. This square is elongated north-south, designed by Bernini in the center of the famous "fountain of four rivers".

Nice area to people watch and just relax. Lucky enough, this was just a 2min stroll from the apt we stayed at so we went here almost every night after having dinner at places that were NOT in the Piazza (better value, better food). It was nice to just sit down and look at the fountains, people, and just soaking in the fact that you are in Rome!

Possibly the most charming of Rome's Piazzas. We were delighted to find the Piazza Navona. It really is a charming and romantic square which felt much more relaxed than the frantic city does generally. The 3 fountains are all beautiful but the central fountain of the 4 rivers is a remarkable work of art, especially when viewed at sunset with the church of St Agnes in Agony as a backdrop. The restaurants and cafes on the square are naturally somewhat overpriced due to their location, but it is worth stoping at least for a coffee and a bit of people watching in one of them in my opinion, just for the experience. All the restaurants do seem to be quite aggressive in trying to get passersby in to their premises however, which can be annoying.

Love this piazza. This is a great place to go for people watching, food, or souvenirs. I enjoyed shopping for souvenirs while looking at the fountains. Even if you don't eat right in the piazza, there are lots of great place in the area and it's a great atmosphere. It's a central location for walking, but there is also a taxi stand just off the piazza. When I was here Metro A only ran until 9 most nights and dinner usually lasted later than that so I made use of the nearby taxis.
Nice place to sit and watch the world go by. Lots to see and living statues etc with a another great fountain. We spent quite a bit of time here just enjoying the sites and sounds.

Picturesque and Romantic. This is a must for all couples.... I visited the place at night for dinner and its very magical, there are artists painting and musician and tons of restaurants all around..its best to start at Trevi fountains and take a nice stroll to Piazza Navona afterwards.

Becoming a third world place. Used to be a very beautiful and nice place to hang around for a bit. It was one of the trademarks of the centre of Rome equivalent to Fontana di Trevi.Unfortunately this is not the case anymore, at least according to my last visit. It is now full of immigrants(?) who are selling their merchandise (mostly fake brand names) in most places around the piaza and especially around the central fountain where they also obstruct people's approach near it - difficult to have a photograph with the fountain as background. Apparently the authorities do not seem to care, not only for this but for other similar situations.In general, having been in that city many times since the mid-90s I gathered the impression that Rome is declining and this is one of the most dissapointing signs of it.

Nice piazza - good place to sit and look at the people. Beautiful piazza, with beautiful fountains. We liked the atmosphere in this piazza. More relaxed than some of the other tourist places. Many bars and restaurant with tables outside. We sat at the Bar Navona and had a glass of wine. Very nice place to sit and relax.

Great place to people watch, get food, and perhaps pick up a souvenir. The Piazza Navona is a great place to get some food, watch the crowds and get souvenirs. The restaurants are reportedly quite expensive in the area, and it is in a prime tourist area, however I felt that the prices were in keeping with quite a lot of Rome. You can see all sorts of activities going on in the square including singers. There are a lot of souvenir stands in the middle so if you want a picture of your visit this is not a bad place to go.

Pretty Square. This square is a bit like the Place du Tetre in Paris as there are lots artists selling their wares in one end. At the other end there are the usual human "statues" who were not very good - it takes more than wrapping yourself in a yellow sheet and wearing a mask to impress me.The free walking tour guide recommended this area for good food and we reckon he was right.

Lovely to walk around and take pictures.....very expensive to eat. We'd read in numerous reviews and books that eating here was expensive, so we planned our trip just to go around the piazza, take some pictures and eat elsewhere. Reflecting on this, i think that was the best choice, as the restaurants seemed very expensive (even compared to normal Rome prices) and we couldn't see one italian person eating here! It did feel like a tourist trap.The piazza is very busy when you first walk in. There seems to be one main entrance, where people just stop and start taking pictures, giving the illusion of it being very crowded. I would highly recommend, arriving in the square and just taking and immediate left or right and walking all the way round the outside. You can get some great views from either end and it is much more peaceful here.Its definitely very pretty but for me this was a view only, not stop and have food or drink here.

Worth a Visit. We enjoyed the Piazza Navona. The statues are pretty amazing as are the fountains. The night life was interesting. There was a Michael Jackson impersonator when we were there. We ate across the street by the subway station at a cheap but good pizza parlor. But, we did not feel it was as lovely as places like Castel Sant' Angelo.

Great Piazza Navona. This Piazza has many restaurants, gift shops and of course the fountains. Great place to get a gillato and just kick back. Very busy and crowded during the late morning and afternoon, but the crowds thin out during the early evening. We didn't eat at ant of the restaurants here as they are very overpriced and didn't get great reviews. But the gillato's were good and reasonably prices.

Really nice!. I have visited Piazza Navona many times and in all periods of the day. It is true to say that this square is a nice attraction that is always booming but mostly during the night. The square is so nice and you can really enjoy the nice monuments of the four rivers. At night Navona is much nicer with a lot of tourists and painters, there are always some kind of shows that are carried by some people there. You can also find some good restaurants around the square with a pleasant seating plan outdoors with some fans that spry you with cold water the thing that refreshes you.

Wonderful, wonderful, wonderful Piazza Navona. Undoubtedly one of my favourite piazzas, Piazza Navona is steeped in elegance and beauty. It is also relatively large and therefore a welcome open space within the city. The fountains can be gazed at interminably although the metal protection around them (presumably to stop people jumping in) takes away some of the magic.The church of St. Agata on the square itself is worth a short visit and offers a welcome respite from the beating sun.There are also many buskers around and the day we were there there was also a political protest going on, making the square all the more interesting and alive.

Great piazza, one of my favorite locations in all of Rome. There is such an openness to this piazza that is so unique. It is very large and was often flooded to have chariot or carriage races around the the fountains. It is surrounded by dining umbrellas from the adjoining restaurants, but we did not eat here. There is a gelato shop on the west side about in the middle, just north of the large white govt??? building. It has a few steps up and next to a small side street (that supposedly leads to a tiny restaurant that is very good, but we were off time for dining) The gelato was generous and gave us time to linger in the piazza and people watch. Exit the north end of the piazza and head east. You will encounter several important and gorgeous churches, the Pantheon, and the Trevi Fountain. It was a wonderful walk. Wear sturdy sandles or walking shoes, as the cobbles will test your ankles, balance, and it's not worth a sprain. I would return here of all places for sure on another trip to Rome. I loved this more in atmosphere than other piazzas. It was a happy place and maybe just good for drinks as the restaurant reviews sound unenticing. One street to the east of the piazza had an outdoor orchestra performance, (pay at the door) set up for that evening amidst columns, on a lawn, chairs set up, that would be great, but again wrong timing. You can't do it all unless you live there!

A stop must be made here- Fountain by Bernini!. One a very impressive piazza in rome. definitely have to make a stop here.it's unique as it's in an oval size shaped and it features one of the most complex statues which its name Fontana Dei Quattro Fiumi or rather the Four Rivers Fountain which was sculpted by Bernini. Also there is a history or tales between boromini and bernini which you could find out further on the net or actually visiting the piazza! :P

It's nice. Just don't eat here. Piazza navona is beautiful especially around sunset. Be sure to admire the fountain in the middle which represents the 4 great rivers. However with that said don't eat here. We ate at tre scalni on our first visit. I had the rissoto al funghi which first may I add that cost 15 euros. It was so salty that I could barely eat it. My father who had the roman style chicken told me it was overbooked and burnt. We tried the restaurant directly across from tre scalni in hopes of a better exprince, but to no avail...the food was just as overpriced and just as bad. But hey at least the beer was good. Save your wallet and your appetite and go to the piazza just to take in the view not the food.

Piazza is nice: check tartufo prices. The Piazza is a nice people watching spot. Fountains are interesting, especially if you read the history behind them. One of the big draws is the tartufo, a very rich dark chocolate ice cream with dark chocolate chunks and cherries in the middle. We went to Tre Scalini because it is the original, but the other places were cheaper (as we found out after the fact). I'm sure that they all taste the same. As with any of the other attractions in Rome, it is always cheaper to eat off the main paths.

Loved the Fountains. For me the enchantment of Piazza Navona were the three fountains. I love all the work of Bernini and he had his hand in all the fountains, especially the Fountain of the Rivers. The Danube River represents Europe, the Plate River represents America, the Ganges represents Asia, and the Nile represents Africa. All the sculptures are very powerful and beautiful. The water of the fountain and the Egyptian obelisk complete the fountain. Bernini was really a genius!
3 beautiful fountains..... ...a church, and restaurants/cafeterias. Nice to walk around but the real good food and drink is located around it and not on it.

entertaining. late afternoon and into the evening there's always something happenning, with street performers and painters.Lively and with full of restaurants, we recommend Zio Cirus,right at a corner, with a fixed menu but he food was actually good and not to pricey, around 10 to 12€ p.p.Beautifull fountains all along the piazza
Fountains and outside dining. Three fountains in a paved square. A must see for Dan Brown novel fans. That middle fountain is pretty large.

Enjoyed our first night at the Piazza Novona. After an over night flight to Rome, we checked into our hotel and later visited the Piazza Navona. What a great start to what turned out to be an awesome vacation. Even being dead tired we really enjoyed the Piazza with the entertainment, art, stores, restaurants and cafe's! We sat in amazement while enjoying our first pizza in Italy at a quaint outdoor pizza shop! The fountains, and buildings were beautiful. A must see while in Rome!

Beautiful, lively during the December.. Ever since I saw "Angels and Demons" I wanted to make a visit to Piazza Navona, I had already done some research because of Bernini's work in some art classes, but the movie sealed the deal in regards to me wanting to visit. I went a couple of weeks before Christmas, the plaza was filled with street vendors selling traditional Christmas ornaments, food, candy, trinkets and so forth; I had read some reviews in which people complained over the vendors, this seems to be a yearly tradition which I thought was a nice addition to the beautiful plaza. I would have liked to see it in all its glory but it just wasn't in the cards for me. The sculptures are beautiful, specially Bernini's Four River's Fountain. Breathtaking.
The Grandest Piazza. If time is short you MUST do the Colosseum, Vatican and St. Peter's Basilica. After that it's all a bonus.

nice spot for an evening meal. we were advised by our B&B that this location would be a go place to hang out in the evening and they were not wrong. on the rim of the piazza there are a dozen italian restaurants, all selling the same food for approx the same price. most of the seating is outdoors so if you do decide to eat here please make sure you bring a jumper if it is a colder month. in terms of atmosphere, there a lots of street entertainers playing music or dancing which is a nice distraction. at the main square are we found a lot of street vendors selling all manner of tat, alongside sellers of paintings which brought the square standard up a bit. all in all a nice place to hang out.

Highly recommended. My family loved this piazza. It is large, centrally located and filled with beautiful fountains, street entertainers, and artists. We liked it so much the first time that we came back the next night. Great people watching, good enternainment, and some very good restaurants just a few blocks away, Nice way to wind down after a hectic day. Plan on staying at least an hour or two.

nice place,..... Three fountains on piazza and bunch of artist with great and less great pictures, then market with Italian scented fruits & vegetables. Really nice. Make shure you visit Navona by day and night.And make sure you try Tartufo ice-cream on north side of Piazza.

Romantic Beautiful Spot in Rome, Love it so Much!. Many great spots in Rome but Piazza Navona is our favorite place for its romantic n beautiful scene, the buildings n statues, the peoples n paintings attractions, fun n happy atmosphere to chill and taking pics, various restaurants offers delicious foods and reasonable prices, with small table n crowded tourists take rest n luch, other is trastevere and near pantheon also hv some good restaurants with exelent food. Very much worth visit when u hv vacation in Rome.

The most beautiful piazza in Rome. The piazza Navona is a must-see in Rome, it has three fountains, one large in the center with an obelisk and two smaller ones in both sides. We had a relaxing time in this attraction after several hours walking the historic center of Rome, we enjoyed sitting around the fountain while we had some snacks. The place was a little crowded but a nice relaxing ambiance and also is close to other attraction like the Pantheon.
i like it so much !. A very nice square with a lovely fountain ... Worth going for a walk and sit on brown (it's expensive to keep in mind)

Our favorite piazza in Rome. We almost skipped it, but came here on our last day and it was definitely worth it. This was our favorite piazza in Rome (Piazza Venezia was second). Vividly colored buildings, beautiful church, white fountain with beautiful water, put it all together and it's just gorgeous, a must see. It's a short walk to/from the Pantheon and Campo de Fiore from the piazza. Bonus: Take a short, less than 10 minute walk to the river from here, and you'll see a beautiful view of a basilica and the river in front of it. Pics attached.
Romantic, beautiful place. Must see place.It is very relaxing, romantic and beautiful.Very close to the city center and the pantheon

Must See. We went to Piazza Navona after seeing the Pantheon and Trevi Fountain (not bad walking distance between these sites, if you are accustomed to & enjoy walking. We went specifically to see Bernini's Fountain of the Four Rivers...it was ok...but the architecture of entire piazza is very lovely & definitely worth the visit. What really makes the visit wothwhile is the church facing the fountains...very nice...actually I recommend whenever you pass a church in Rome, if you have time, take a peek inside, as most are dilled with amzing craftsmanship & neat paintings.

A Bustling Square. The piazza is flanked with restaurants, which were quite pricey. We found a little shop just off the square selling panini’s for €2 - €3 so we had one of those whilst sitting on one of the benches and people watching. There were lots of stalls inside the square, people selling paintings, caricatures, trinkets etc.

Visit the Church. Beautiful piazza, beautiful fountains... and beautiful church. Unfortunately, many people just seat by one of the fountains, eat gelato, and leave . Visit the Church of Sant' Agnese in Agone. Seat inside for 5-10 minutes and think about good things others have done for you. The piazza will look different when you step out of the Church.

Another attractive piazza. We ate gelato while taking time out sitting on the edge of one of the fountains in Piazza Navona. It was late afternoon and we were getting tired after spending an entire day walking around Rome (including the Colosseum, the Forum and Palatine Hill). The piazza was still busy at this time. Though we didn't notice any performers etc, it was full of beautiful sculptures and fountains surrounded by beautiful buildings. Maybe it was the tiredness, but truly for us we saw it as just another attractive Roman piazza.

Beautiful! Don't miss out on this gorgeous square!. We go to Rome almost every year and I don't think we missed a chance to visit Piazza Navona so far. It’s a gorgeous place to visit any time of the year with all the buildings and fountains. If you are there around December/January, you have yet another reason to check it out: a Christmas/Befana market (I think it’s open from early December to early January every year). It’s really pretty with a carrousel, fair food, and lots of stands selling cute souvenirs.Parking is always difficult in Rome. We usually try to find a good spot close to the Castel Sant’Angelo and walk over (maybe 10 minutes or so).Find more details and pictures on my blog: http://countryskipper.com/2011/02/28/a-christmas-market-in-rome-check-out-piazza-navona/

Not worth it in the rain!. We went on a rainy day and what everyone else is describing is cetainly not what we got.l It simp0ly was just a piazza with a fountain i9n the middle. I wouldnt recommend you visit on a rainy day as it seems that the street performers and crowds seem to make it worthwhile it is cerainly not when those things are absent.

Large, relaxing and impessive.. Upon my fist glance at this amazing piazza I was awe struck. The size, the marvelous baroque architecture and, of course, Bernini's magnificent fountains. The Brazilian Embassy building was particularly beautiful. Grab an over priced gelato, find a bench, relax for a while and enjoy.

Beautiful fountains. The fountains were beautiful! This piazza is very busy. A lot of people even in the middle of winter. Also around Christmas time, there are tents set up everywhere with people selling goods that range from candy to toys for children to enjoy as well as jewelry and other goods that adults would enjoy. There are nice shops and restaurants that surround the piazza and a lot of small stores that you can shop from. A great place to just walk around and get lost even in the little streets that branch off from the piazza. Nice place to sit at the fountains and just relax and people watch.

The Piazza Navona is the most famous.... The Piazza Navona is the most famous and beautiful of Rome's many squares. When one is taking photos of the square, you can't miss the baroque church of Sant' Agnese in Agone.The Piazza Navona is situated on the historic center of Rome, west of the Pantheon.

Beautiful. We visited here as a part of the Angels and Demons tour and loved it so much we stayed and had lunch. Artists and musicians are strolling the plaza and the entire area is enchanting along with the party at the Brazilizan embassy going on while we were there.

Beautiful piazza. We visited Pazza Novona early morning before it became too busy and it was absolutely beautiful. The buildings and fountains are outstanding. We went back later in the day and it was very crowded with artists and street performers - the piazza had a very different feel but was still a good place to visit.Probably the most beautiful of the Roman piazzas.

Santana's Rival: Street Musician in Piazza Navona. We have a video of this amazing musician. Our only regret is that we didn't buy his CD....thought we'd be back and travel plans changed. He was fabulous! Rivals Santana! We know for sure he was playing at Piazza Navona June 8 & 9, and July 1st this summer. He wore a hat..... DOES ANYONE HAPPEN TO KNOW WHO THIS MUSICIAN IS???
Very pretty. Very pretty square, loved the architecture here. Would definately go back again for another cappucino.

It was nice but nothig special was in.... It was nice but nothig special was in it.It was a nice place for gathering but ends at 11:00 pm as all the resturants are closed bi 10:30 pm.There was a nice fountin in the middle and small church but thats it.
Fun times!. Great square that is a fun place for dinner and people watching! Enjoy the street vendors, walk around and soak up the atmosphere!

Piazza Navona - impressive but not my fav. A must - Piazza Navonna. Signs from Trevi Fountain lead to the Theatre, Pantheon then Piazza Navona. From there visit Campo Fiori, its market place and shopping along Via Giubbonari, which runs to Via Arenula. From there head back up to Via Vittorio Emmanuele and see the ruins of the Sacred Place.

Wonderful. This square was a much appreciated break in a beautyfull walk through Rome. The square is a perfect place to take a break if walking between the vatican and the historical center of Rome. The square has several restaurants which can be quite expensive, but which are perfect to sit down to take a drink and to just relax and watch the life on the square. Enjoyed one of the most appreciated beers i've ever tasted at this square.

the artists piazza. This is a beautiful elongated piazza in Rome built over the stadium built by the Emperor Domitian. There are 3 large fountains infront of the church of Sant' Agnese. The piazza is full of very expensive restaurants selling bad food for high prices. The piazza is also full of artisans of all types - musicians, romans, people dressed as statues/mummies and people of all sorts. Quite an experience, but don't get ripped off!

Beautiful, lively public area. There are ripoff artists (the Centurions) and bad meals to be found almost anywhere in Rome, but this was our favorite public area during our most recent visit, nicer than Trevi Fountain or the Spanish Steps. The two fountains were beautiful, and we enjoyed the artist stalls and street performers. And try the special gelato (chocolate covering a cherry) at Tre Scalini.

Roman Centurion Entertainers RipOff. When you get to Piazza Navona, which is a beauty you will be welcomed by Roman Centurions in full costume who entice you to take photos with them and they encourage a large number of passers by.They then charge you Ten Euros for a 2 second job just for having them in the picture. They never mention the charge before they stand by you - only after!I challenged them whether they were engaged by the Mayor but they said no and that they had to gain their everyday bread and butter. WoW !!They make something like 10 Euros per minute what with the flow of tourists in Piazza Navona.Beware of the Roman Centurion Entertainers in Piazza Navona. They will RipOff your money !!!

Good food just off Piazza Navona.. Piazza Navona is a beautiful space, with some ugly restaurants. I haven't eaten in them all but the ones I have tried, (no names), have been too expensive, for poor food. The general 'vibe' is you are paying for the view, not the food. However, if you want good food, exit the piazza mid way up, on to the narrow Via di Tor Millina and pop into number 27, a restaurant called Cybo.It has only been open as a restaurant for three weeks, so we may have experienced it at its best. It's modern Italian, with contemporary feel. It has a very well stocked, U.S. Style bar, that most will feel at home in. The food is carefully prepared, extremely tasty and reasonably priced, (even at a poor £/Euro rate). Service is friendly and professional. My wife and I ate here three times during our seven day break and amongst other things sampled the excellent mixed starters, with battered and fried vegetables, cold cuts and a delicious take on the usually bland artichoke. There are the usual starters of prosciutto, bresaola, mozzarella, suppli etc. Pasta dishes are first rate, secondi limited to steak done various ways, scalopine and a few fish dishes. Desserts run to the usual favourites of panacotta, tiramisu etc. but all done with care. The wine list is short(ish) but adequate, with low mark-ups. There is quite a large cocktail list.

Wonderful square populated with some impressive artists. This is probably my second favourite place in Rome after the Colosseum. It is a people watching place and is made by the wonderful fountains at both ends, the statue in the middle and some of the buildings around the edges. In addition artists display their wares, and it is possible to pay over the odds for a nice cup of coffee and watch the world go by.

Very nice, beautiful church & artwork stalls. Piazza Navona is famous for their fountains - the 4 rivers fountain – Fontana dei Quattro Fiumi – but it is also under restoration and completely covered. There is glass at every sculpture, so one can actually see it but it almost all obscured by scaffolding. There are also market stalls with all the artwork fro sale, very very nice. Also visit the other fountains – Fontana del Nettuno and Fontana del Moro. We watch some sort of magic show and a non-moving street performer for a few moments and continue into the church. St Agatha (or Agnes?) – Sant’Agnese in Agone – is very beautiful inside. St Agatha’s (Agnes) very tiny skull is also in the church in a side room, a little gruesome, but there it was. I found out later, she was a 13 year old girl killed in 304 AD for her refusal to renounce Christianity. The church is connected to Palazzo Pamphilj, which is supposed to be the Brazilian embassy. The Piazza Navona is a very lovely square to visit and I enjoyed my time there.

Terrific large square with beautiful fountains, local artists, good wine, etc.. Sure, it's expensive to drink there, but for 18 Euros we had an appetizer, a bottle of wine, and an hour or two sitting outside near the beautiful Fontana di Nettuno (fountain), soaking it all in. It's a great place to relax in Roma.

Roman Atmosphere. Piazza Navona is a large courtyard that contains sculptures / fountains at either end., which we had visited before the vandalism mentioned by the previous posts. Around the outside are shops / eateries. Sit to eat and have a relaxing lunch or dinner. Great atmosphere – good place to sit and watch the world pass by. We did notice that the restaurants right in the piazza are slightly more expensive than others nearby.Several vendors at the plaza were selling counterfeit purses / bags. The women in our tour enjoyed bargaining to get cheap imitation items. The vendors put up a weak front at first claiming that the items are real, but come down very quickly in price if you negotiate firmly. Police here and in other areas of Italy didn’t seem to take much notice of this type of counterfeit sales, although we did see some of the vendors pack up briefly when police were near and then set up again as soon as they were gone. Don’t be suckered in by guys offering to weave bracelets / jewelry. One girl in our group let them put one on her wrist and then demanded to be paid for it after. He wouldn’t take it back and wouldn’t take no for an answer. Eventually she gave him a few coins (far less than he was demanding) and left. We found similar activities to be quite prevalent in Rome. Be aware of anyone who seems to be offering help or gifts as they likely will want to be paid for it.

Fun for the Family. We Visited December 16th 2006 .The centre fountain is still covered and undergoing restoration ,but there are glass panels on one side to give you some idea of its great beauty if you haven't visited before.A deffinate must see on a revisit - it's breathtaking.Remember there are two more wonderfull fountains on this characterfull piazza. There is always some kind of 'booth' market / fair here .A childs delight ,one of the few places where there is definately something for them. We watched a frozen statue for ages as the small children dropped coins in his pot. A dark halloween type figure ,white face /black eyes (closed) stooped and holding a fake cat.At the chink of a coin he moved,smiled , the eyes opened looked at you and rolled ,and the cat screeched too.So much pleasure to so many for so little.The best one we saw.A must do for those visiting with children.

The fountain is covered up!. I went to Rome the week of October 8 and when we went to the Piazza Navona, the fountain was completely boarded up! They had a little exhibit to the side in Italian and from what we could make out, apparently the fountain had been vandelized and they were in the process of cleaning and restoring it. What a shame. Due to that, the other two fountains were sectioned off by gates and there was heavy police presence as well.We did eat a nice little caffe called Cafe Bernini I believe. However, it would have been beautiful had the fountains been visible.

So much to see! Family of 5 from NJ, USA. Great spot to visit and people watch. Lots of vendors and artists. The fountains are beautiful.Had a wonderful meal overlooking The Piazza, shop around and check menus and prices, a side street will always have a better buy! Plan to bargain for prints, knock off designer bags,etc! It's all there!

Great place - don't dip your feet in the fountain though!. A great place for eating/drinking in the centre of Rome - don't dip your feet in the fountain though - the local police are very strict about that !! Lots of mime artists, street vendors, entertainers, huge choice of restaurants, including those in the little cobbled side streets. Drinks are expensive but food is reasonable.

Bad Experience at the Piazza. We recently went to Rome to a wedding and the bride and groom had arranged for everyone to meet at Piazza Navona for dinner on the day after the wedding. We had heard so many great and wondering things about the Piazza that we felt we really have to go and see this place for ourselves. The piazza is vibrant and alive with things to do and see. The magnificent statues, fountains and architect is second to none and I could recommend seeing the piazza to anyone. The problems started when we went to have something to eat. We chose the Cafe Di Columbia in which to have dinner and from the start it was a disaster. The waiter did not want to take an order for 28 people and insisted that we all either eat the same food or handing the paper and pen to the bride, insisted she take the order herself and bring it to him. Customer service at its worse in my opinion. I personally wanted to leave the restaurant and go elsewhere but seeing as it the newly married couple who chose this venue I thought it best to stay put and not offend anyone. The bride eventually took the order and after an hour of watiing the food came out. I should have left !!! The food was either undercooked, overcooked or just plain didn't arrive. One of the group is still waiting today for her childs order. My expectation of fine italian dining did not live up to expectations at this establishment and i would not recommend large groups to go to this venue. I don't think that they can cope. We left the piazza hungry and disappointed at what was supposed to be a unique dining experience.

A little piece of heaven on earth. Little did I know that when I went to Rome I'd be falling in love with a Piazza! Piazza Navona did this and more and I spent more of my week there than most other places. This is definitely Rome at its most flamboyant and fabulous, Bernini and Borromini's Baroque Rome in all its theatrical finery. If you have an artists or musicians soul this is your place.From the fabulous fountains and you can't fail to be enchanted by the the Fountain of Four Rivers and Neptune and his wonderful water world. The gorgeous cafes and bars are all round the square especially the wonderful Tre Scalini who serve the totally decadent chocoholics dream dessert the 'Tartuffo'. The food is cooked to perfection too, but you can just as easily drink wine and coffee and just sit and soak up the atmosphere in this little piece of heaven on earth and people watch the world go by. From day to night the place changes magically and I urge you to spend a day here just marvelling at everything going on, from seeing Caravaggio's hanging on walls... to street artists and entertainers giving this magical square an atmosphere all of its own. Spend the morning then visit the Pantheon and the Trevi or wherever you want to go BUT please come back for the evening and see the change.You'll be totally glad that you did and you'll want to come back so throw those coins in the Trevi.

The best of Bernini. Piazza Navona is the best of all of the Bernini fountians. A great place to people watch, relax at a outdoor cafe and absorb the flavor of Rome! Don't just rush through this piazza on a tour. Early morning or late at night Navona has a life of it's own. Children with bubble guns, artists, and musicians in the evening. Dolce Vita!

A beautiful refuge. A really wonderful place to sit and watch the interesting world of a foreign city. The most beautiful Piazza in Rome in my humble opinion. The outdoor cafes surrounding the Piazza are a must-do, even if you only have a cappuccino (They'll let you sit and soak-up the enchanting surroundings without bothering you for the check).While all the wonderful sites of antiquity in the city are a must-see, don't pass up the uniquely Italian experience of just relaxing in a Piazza and absorbing the local scene. I was surprised at how much I enjoyed just sitting and taking in the scene - One of my most pleasant and memorable evening experiences.

Great Place to People-Watch. Piazza Navona was a vibrant, busy square, with one or two particularly good value bar/restaurants around. Our particular favourite (we visited over the weekend of Feb 10/11/12) was the Cafe di Colombia, where the waiters were very friendly, no hard-sell, spoke very good english and were happy to chat or leave you be, as you wished. The street musicians were at least professional standard, the artists similar, and even the nuisance purveyors of cheap rubbish (plastic toys, glow in the dark wristbands, you know the stuff I mean) were less obtrusive than I've seen them elsewhere. The Piazza is pedestrianised, so a great place to take children, and if you're into such things, is surrounded by alleyways containing a succession of interesting antique shops. There are a lot worse places to pass the evening after a busy days' site-seeing.

Absolutely Amazing!. We knew nothing about this piazza until we happened to walk to it from the Pantheon. I was stunned at the place (and after three days in Rome, it took quite a bit to stun me). It was truly a wonderful place and (as I found out later) it's highly recommended.This is a must see.

Wonderful in the evenings. Piazza Navona is alive in the evenings. There are 2 beautiful fountains. There are many restaurants/pizzarias to choose from. There is even an old toy store with a large Pinnochio out front that you can pose for pictures with. There are artists selling their drawings. This is a wonderful place to wander in the evening.

Heaven on Earth. What a beautiful piazza, three fountains and lots of night life. I have traveled all over the great cities of Europe and Piazza Navona has stayed at the top of my list for years. My husband enjoys all the entertainment in evening hours and my daughter loves all the local artist. Every trip we have brought art from local artist in Piazza Navona and look forward to adding more to our collection in the summer of 2004. My husband and I will be traveling with first time visitors to Rome and will especially love sharing this place with them.

Nice enough. Nice enough plaza, the fountains are attractive. Take a look in the church on the west side (St. Agnes of the Flames, I think) it's an impressive intereior. For that matter look in any church you see; even the small ones are gorgeous.
